Introduction
Praise be to Allah who sent His Messenger with guidance and the religion of truth to manifest it over all religion, although those who associate others with Allah dislike it. I bear witness that there is no deity except Allah alone, with no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, the seal of the prophets and messengers, may Allah bless him and his family and companions all together, and those who follow them in goodness until the Day of Judgment.
To proceed:
This is a brief research on the Maturidiyyah (1), and it includes a preface and five chapters:
Preface, containing three sections:
Section One: Definition of Maturidiyyah and its founder.
Section Two: Its emergence.
Section Three: Reasons for the spread of Maturidiyyah.

Topic One: Knowledge of Allah is obligatory according to them by reason before the arrival of revelation.

Preface
Section One: Definition of Maturidiyyah:
Maturidiyyah: An innovative theological sect attributed to Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi. It was established on using rational and theological proofs and evidences in arguing with its opponents, such as the Mu'tazila, Jahmiyyah, and others, to prove the truths of religion and Islamic creed (1).
Definition of Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi.
1 - His Lineage and Life:
He is Abu Mansur Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Mahmoud bin Muhammad Al-Maturidi (2) Al-Samarqandi Al-Hanafi, the Theologian (Mutakallim). Ancient sources did not mention his birth date, but some contemporaries mentioned his birth date as approximately 238 AH, and Allah knows best (3). Others mentioned his birth was in 258 AH. As for his death, biographers of Al-Maturidi agreed that he died in the year (333 AH) (4).
He received knowledge of Hanafi jurisprudence and theology from the scholars of that era, including Nasr bin Yahya Al-Balkhi who died in 268 AH, and others from the senior Hanafi scholars, such as Abu Nasr Al-Ayadi, Abu Bakr Ahmad Al-Juzjani, and Abu Sulayman Al-Juzjani, until he became one of the senior Hanafi scholars. Some famous figures in theology studied under him. Abu Mansur had - according to his creed - numerous debates and arguments with the Mu'tazila in matters where he disagreed with them, and he has many books in various arts.

He was titled in Transoxiana as the Imam of Sunnah and the Imam of Guidance - according to the Maturidiyyah - (1). He stood against the Mu'tazila who were in Transoxiana, yet he was close to them in his view of reason, though he did not go to their extremes. Instead, he considered it another source in addition to the primary source, which is revelation (Naql), prioritizing revelation over reason when they contradict. However, he considers knowledge of Allah obligatory by reason before the arrival of revelation, and that Allah punishes for the lack of this knowledge (2). Abdullah Al-Mara'i said in the book (Al-Fath Al-Mubin) in the biographies of Usulis: "Abu Mansur was strong in argument, fierce in dispute, defended the beliefs of Muslims - meaning the Maturidiyyah -, and refuted the doubts of atheists" (3).
2 - His Works:
Al-Maturidi has many works, including:
1 - The exegesis known as (Ta'wilat Ahl Al-Sunnah) or (Ta'wilat Al-Quran), which is well-known and famous among the Maturidiyyah, and no other exegesis equals it for them, neither before nor after it.
2 - Book of (Al-Tawhid), considered one of his most important theological works; because he established his theological theories in it and clarified his belief in the most important doctrinal issues.
3 - A treatise on Faith (Iman).
4 - Al-Maqalat (The Articles), considered one of the oldest books on sects; due to the early time of its author, but the book is lost.
5 - Bayan Wahm Al-Mu'tazila (Exposing the Delusion of the Mu'tazila).
6 - Radd Tahdhib Al-Jadal (Refutation of the Refinement of Dialectic).
7 - Radd Wa'id Al-Fussaq (Refutation of the Threat to Sinners).
8 - Radd Awa'il Al-Adilla (Refutation of the First Proofs).
9 - Radd Al-Usul Al-Khamsa (Refutation of the Five Principles) by Abu Muhammad Al-Bahili.
10 - Refutation of the Qarmatians.
11 - Radd Al-Imamah (Refutation of the Imamate), which is a refutation of some Rafidis.
12 - Ma'akhidh Al-Shara'i (Sources of Laws).
13 - Al-Jadal (Dialectic) (4).

3 - His Sheikhs and Students:
First: His Sheikhs:
1 - Muhammad bin Muqatil Al-Razi, narrated from Waki' and his generation. He was criticized and not abandoned. He died in the year two hundred and forty-eight, and has works including Al-Mudda'i wa Al-Mudda'a 'Alayh (The Plaintiff and the Defendant) (1).
2 - Abu Nasr Al-Ayadi Ahmad bin Al-Abbas bin Al-Hussein bin Jabalah Al-Samarqandi. He was a man of knowledge and Jihad, and had no narration or Hadith. He was captured by the disbelievers and killed in captivity in the land of the Turks during the days of Nasr bin Ahmad bin Ismail bin Asad bin Saman.
3 - Abu Bakr Ahmad bin Ishaq Al-Juzjani. He combined the science of Usul (Principles) and the science of Furu' (Branches), and was of high rank in various sciences. He has the book (Al-Farq wa Al-Tamyiz) and the book (Al-Tawbah) and others.
4 - Nusayr bin Yahya Al-Balkhi, also said Nasr. He was proficient in Hanafi jurisprudence and theology, died in the year 268 AH (2).
Second: His Students:
1 - Abu Al-Qasim Ishaq bin Muhammad bin Ismail bin Ibrahim bin Zaid, the Wise Judge of Samarkand. He took jurisprudence and theology from Al-Maturidi, and is considered one of his most famous students. Abu Al-Mu'in mentioned that he died in the year 335 AH, and it was said 342 AH.
2 - Abu Al-Hasan Ali bin Saeed Al-Rustughfani, attributed to Rustughfan, a village of Samarkand. Al-Rustughfani was described by his biographers as one of the senior Sheikhs of Samarkand and one of the major companions of Al-Maturidi, and he is mentioned in jurisprudence and principles in Hanafi books.
3 - Abu Muhammad Abdul Karim bin Musa bin Isa Al-Faqih Al-Bazdawi. He studied jurisprudence under Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi, heard and narrated. He excelled in jurisprudence specifically. Al-Qurashi said he mentioned in the History of Nasaf that he died in the year 390 AH in Ramadan.
4 - Abu Ahmad bin Abi Nasr Ahmad bin Al-Abbas Al-Ayadi, who is the son of Abu Nasr Al-Ayadi, the Sheikh of Al-Maturidi.
5 - Abu Abdul Rahman bin Abi Al-Layth Al-Bukhari. He took theology and jurisprudence from Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi, and he is a companion of Abu Al-Qasim the Wise of Samarkand (3).
6 - Abu Al-Yusr Al-Bazdawi (493 AH).

Section Two: Emergence of the Maturidiyyah
The emergence of the Maturidiyyah began at the end of the third century at the hands of Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi. It was characterized by intense debates with the Mu'tazila and others. He had his rounds against the Mu'tazila and others, but with a methodology different from Al-Ash'ari's, although they met in many results. However, historical sources do not prove a meeting or correspondence between them, or viewing each other's books.
Then after that, Abu Mansur had students who worked on spreading the ideas of their Sheikh and Imam, defended them, and wrote classifications following the school of Imam Abu Hanifa in Furu' (rulings). This was a reason for the popularity of the Maturidi creed in Samarkand.
Then, after the spread of Maturidiyyah, its followers became active in writing. They authored works explaining the Maturidi creed and establishing it. One of the most famous authors was Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi (438 - 508 AH): He is Maimun bin Muhammad bin Mu'tamid Al-Nasafi Al-Makhuli. He is considered one of the most famous Maturidi scholars and one of the greatest supporters of the Maturidi school. He is to the Maturidiyyah what Al-Baqillani and Al-Ghazali are to the Ash'aris. Among his most important books is (Tabsira Al-Adilla), considered one of the most important references in knowing the Maturidi creed after the book (Al-Tawhid) by Al-Maturidi; rather, it is the most extensive reference in Maturidi creed absolutely. He summarized it in his book (Al-Tamhid). He also has the book (Bahr Al-Kalam), which is one of the concise books in which he addressed the most important theological issues.
Also among them is Najm Al-Din Umar Al-Nasafi (462 - 537 AH). He had many Sheikhs, and many people learned from him. He has works reaching a hundred, including: (Majma' Al-Ulum), (Al-Taysir fi Tafsir Al-Quran), (Al-Najah fi Sharh Kitab Akhbar Al-Sihah fi Sharh Al-Bukhari) and the book of creeds famous as (Al-Aqa'id Al-Nasafiyyah), which is considered one of the most important texts in Maturidi creed, and is a summary of (Tabsira Al-Adilla) by Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi.
The matter continues to expand and spread with the abundance of writing Maturidi books of: texts, explanations, explanations of explanations, and footnotes on explanations. Schools that adopt the call to Maturidiyyah, especially in the Indian subcontinent like the Deobandi school, the Barelvi school, and others (1).

Section Three: Reasons for the Spread of Maturidiyyah
The Maturidiyyah spread in various places for reasons, the most important of which are as follows:
1 - The main reason, indeed the most important reason, is the adherence of Sultans and Kings to the Hanafi school. Because of that, the Hanafi school spread in the east and west of the earth, among Arabs and non-Arabs, Persians and Romans. With the spread of Hanafism and the influence of their authority, Maturidiyyah spread, because the Maturidis represented the Hanafi school in Furu' (rulings). It is known in history throughout the centuries that if any state leans towards a certain school, it facilitates and provides its scholars with positions of judiciary, fatwa, leadership, sermonizing, writing, and teaching. Thus, they find many reasons and easy ways to extend their authority and influence over peoples and homelands. The state also encourages them by establishing schools and mosques, thereby spreading their ideas and increasing their activity (1). Thus, Maturidiyyah and their beliefs spread in the lands of Transoxiana, the Turks, the Afghans, India, China, and adjacent areas.
This reason for spreading the Maturidi creed in India and its surroundings was strengthened by the fact that the scholars and sheikhs who came to India during the eras of Muslim kings: most of them were scholars from Transoxiana whose main reliance was on the books of late Hanafi jurists, and their care for the books of Sunnah was weak, and they were influenced by Greek sciences.
2 - Maturidi Schools and their Scholarly and Teaching Activity: Maturidi schools have a great role in spreading their creed. In the history of the Ottoman Empire, Hanafism and Maturidiyyah served simultaneously. The authority of Maturidiyyah expanded according to the expansion of the authority of the Ottoman Empire. Most judges, muftis, mosque preachers, and school heads were Hanafi in branches and Maturidi in creed.
3 - Activity of Maturidis in the Field of Writing: Maturidis have significant activity and continuous endeavor in the field of classifying books in theology. These books spread, and with their spread and teaching, the Maturidi creed spread (2).
4 - Other matters which collectively form a strong reason for their spread and people's influence by them, which are as follows:
a- Their appearing as Ahl al-Sunnah, indeed their claim: that they and the Ash'aris represent Ahl al-Sunnah.
b- Their accusation of the pure Ahl al-Sunnah and the People of Hadith of Anthropomorphism (Tajsim) and Likening (Tashbih) and the like.
c- Their affiliation to the Salaf, especially to the Imams: "Abu Hanifa" and "Al-Shafi'i".
d- The abundance of truth they possess compared to the falsehood possessed by others from the people of innovation.
e- Their refutation of false sects like the early Jahmiyyah, Mu'tazila, Kharijites, Rafidis, and others.
f- The weakness of some pure Ahl al-Sunnah and People of Hadith in spreading the creed of the Salaf, clarifying the truth, and refuting the opponent (3).

text:
Topic One: Reliance on Intellect
The Maturidiyyah divided the fundamentals of religion into "Rationalities" (Aqliyyat) and "Auditories" (Sam'iyyat), and based on that their stance on Revelation (Naql) in the chapter of what they call "Rationalities". So any text that contradicted their minds in "Rationalities", if it was from solitary news (Ahad), they rejected it, and if it was from concurrent news (Mutawatir), they distorted it or interpreted it with various corrupt interpretations. As for what relates to the Hereafter (Ma'ad), they do not interpret it (1).
The source of reception for the Maturidiyyah is the Intellect. Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi says: "Knowledge of Allah and His command is an accident that is not perceived except by inference" (2). Meaning: by inferential knowledge based on rational consideration.
He said in his interpretation of the Almighty's saying: {[We sent] messengers as bringers of good tidings and warners so that mankind will have no argument against Allah after the messengers. And ever is Allah Exalted in Might and Wise} [An-Nisa: 165]: "The reality of the argument for all that is only in acts of worship and laws whose way of knowing is hearing (revelation) not intellect, so it is not [an argument]. As for religion, the way of its necessity is by intellect, so they have no argument against Allah in that" (3).
The Maturidiyyah also made most discussions of Divinity "Rationalities", making "Hearing" subordinate to Intellect in them. Among these Rationalities are those eight attributes which they call rational affirmative attributes, and they also call them (attributes of meanings). They rely in proving them on rational arguments which they view as definitive. As for Sharia texts, they mention them for support, not for reliance (4).
As for discussions of the Hereafter and Prophethoods, they made them auditory (Sam'iyyat), and they express Sam'iyyat as Legalities (Shar'iyyat) as well. They defined Shar'iyyat as matters whose possibility, affirmation or negation, the intellect judges decisively, but there is no way for the intellect to [know] them. As for Rationalities, they are what are not like that (5). Some of them made discussions of Prophethoods from the category of Rationalities (6).

The Maturidiyyah do not claim absolute power for the intellect, as the intellect according to them perceives the appearances of things but does not perceive their essence and realities. Al-Maturidi explains this saying: "Intellects were created finite, falling short of encompassing the totality of things, and understandings fall short of reaching the ultimate end of the matter" (1). In doing so, they try to reach their goal, which is attempting to mediate between Reason and Revelation. This pushed them to divide beliefs into: Divinities and Prophethoods which reason independently proves, and Auditories (Sam'iyyat) which reason does not independently prove and are only perceived by Hearing (Revelation) (2).
This methodology by which the Maturidiyyah attempts to mediate between Reason and Revelation is fundamentally based on a false idea, which is that the texts of Revelation contradict the judgments of Reason. This alleged contradiction is in reality the path of the Philosophers originally, who do not affirm Prophethoods and do not see the sending of Messengers and what they brought as established truths. Their source in inferring the proof of matters is Reason; what Reason affirms is affirmed, and what it negates is negated.
Imam Abu Al-Muzaffar Al-Sam'ani, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Know that the separation between us and the innovators is the issue of Reason; for they founded their religion on the rational and made following and tradition subordinate to the rational. As for Ahl al-Sunnah, they said: The origin in religion is following, and intellects are followers. If the foundation of religion were on the rational, creation would have dispensed with Revelation and Prophets, peace be upon them, and the meaning of command and prohibition would be void, and whoever wished would say whatever he wished. If religion were built on the rational, it would be necessary not to allow believers to accept things until they reasoned them.
When we contemplate the generality of what came in the matter of religion regarding the mention of Allah Almighty's attributes and what people worshiped (by believing), as well as what appeared among Muslims and circulated among them and transmitted from their predecessors until they attributed it to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding the mention of the punishment of the grave, the questioning of the two angels, the Basin, the Balance, the Path, the descriptions of the Fire, and the eternal abode of the two parties in them; these are matters whose realities are not perceived by our intellects, but rather the command came to accept them and believe in them. So if we hear something from the matters of religion and reason it and understand it, then to Allah belongs the praise for that and thanks, and from Him is success. And what we cannot perceive and understand and our intellects do not reach, we believe in it, confirm it, and believe that this is from His Lordship and Power, and we suffice in that with His Knowledge and Will. Allah Almighty said: {And they ask you, [O Muhammad], about the soul. Say, "The soul is of the affair of my Lord. And mankind have not been given of knowledge except a little."} [Al-Isra: 85], and He Almighty said: {And they encompass not a thing of His knowledge except for what He wills} [Al-Baqarah: 255]."
Then he said, may Allah have mercy on him: "Indeed, it is upon us to accept what we reasoned with faith and confirmation, and what we did not reason we accept with submission and surrender. This is the meaning of the saying of the sayer from Ahl al-Sunnah: Islam is a bridge that is not crossed except by submission" (3).

Topic Two: Abandoning Argumentation with Ahad Hadiths in Creed
Among the methodological principles of the Maturidiyyah in establishing creed is not using solitary Hadiths (Ahad) as proof in matters of beliefs. They do not argue except with the Quran or concurrent (Mutawatir) Hadiths, and they do not establish creed with the Quran or Hadith unless the text is definitive in indication (1). They said that solitary Hadiths yield conjecture (Zann) and do not yield certain knowledge (Yaqin), due to the occurrence of doubt in it being the news of the Messenger, because of the lack of security from fabrication of Hadiths against the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him (2). They said they are accepted in legal rulings; as a precaution in the matter and taking with firmness, and because Mutawatir is not found in every incident, so if the solitary report were rejected, rulings would be suspended (3).
Al-Maturidi stated the non-argumentation with solitary Hadiths in creeds in the book (Al-Tawhid) and in (Al-Ta'wilat). He mentioned that the solitary report does not necessitate knowledge because it does not reach the rank of the concurrent report in necessitating knowledge and testimony, but it must be acted upon. He used as evidence for the obligation of acting upon the solitary report Allah's command to those fit for understanding religion to stay behind from Jihad to warn their people when they return to them (4).
The Maturidiyyah in reality do not argue with authentic solitary Hadiths in practical legal rulings absolutely. Rather, for a Hadith to be accepted by them, it must agree with their rules and principles which they established. More than one of them has stated this. Abu Zaid Al-Dabbusi said in (Ta'sis Al-Nazar): "The principle according to our companions is that the solitary report, when it comes contradicting the principles themselves, such as what was narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he obliged ablution from touching the penis, our companions did not accept this report because it came contradicting the principles" (5).

The saying of the Maturidiyyah and those who agreed with them regarding the non-authoritativeness of solitary Hadiths in beliefs is a saying with no basis; rather, it is innovated and modern. Dividing what was narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, into Mutawatir and Ahad is a division that was not known in the era of the Companions and Followers. Also, the saying that the solitary report does not yield knowledge is a saying innovated by the Qadariyyah and Mu'tazila, and their intent by it was to reject Hadiths and refuse them because they are evidence against them (1).
Imam Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, stated the consensus of Muslims on the authoritativeness of the solitary report in Al-Risalah where he said: "If it were permissible for anyone to say in the knowledge of the elite: Muslims ancient and modern agreed on confirming the solitary report and ending with it, such that no one from the jurists of Muslims is known except that he confirmed it, it would be permissible for me" (2). He said after stating the authoritativeness of the solitary report: "And the path of our predecessors and the generations after them until those we witnessed has not ceased to be this path" (3).
The saying of the authoritativeness of the solitary report in beliefs and rulings is the school of Imam Malik, may Allah have mercy on him, as mentioned about him by Muhammad bin Ahmad known as Ibn Khuwayz Mindad (4). It is also the saying of Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him. Al-Marwadhi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "I said to Abu Abdullah: Here are two who say: The report necessitates action but does not necessitate knowledge. He faulted it and said: I do not know what this is..." (5).
It is not known from Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, that he said the solitary report does not yield knowledge, or that he differentiated in accepting it between beliefs and actions; rather, what was reported from him is accepting Hadiths without differentiation. It was narrated from him that he said: "If the Hadith comes from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, we do not deviate from it to other than it and we take it" (6). This is the school of the Salaf and the majority of Muhaddithin and Usulis.

Topic Three: The Saying of Metaphor (Majaz)
The Maturidiyyah went to say that Metaphor occurs in language, the Quran, and Hadith. Ibn Al-Humam said: "Metaphor occurs in language, the Quran, and Hadith" (1). What pushed them to this is their belief that carrying texts on their literal meanings necessitates Anthropomorphism (Tajsim) and Likening (Tashbih). Al-Bayadi said: "Since carrying those texts on their literal meanings of physical limbs, spatial occupancy, and psychological affections was not possible due to the prohibition of definitive proofs, and it was not permissible to invalidate the original due to the lack of comprehending the reality of the description without modality (Bi-la Kayf), they are carried on metaphor from the attributes without modality" (2).
The saying of Metaphor according to Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah is a modern innovated saying with no basis. The early Imams of language like Al-Khalil bin Ahmad, Sibawayh, and Abu Amr bin Al-Ala' did not speak of it. Also, this division is not found among the Imams of Jurists and Usulis. Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, was the first to speak in the science of Usul, and his most important book in this science, (Al-Risalah), has reached us, and there is not the slightest indication in this book to this division, neither near nor far. Likewise, Imam Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Shaybani in his book Al-Jami' Al-Kabir did not speak in it with the term of Truth (Haqiqa) and Metaphor (Majaz). Also, this division was not transmitted from any one of the Imams like Malik, Abu Hanifa, Al-Thawri, Al-Awza'i, and others (3).
Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Whoever says from the Usulis... that he knows Truth from Metaphor by ways including the text of the people of language on that by saying this is truth and this is metaphor, has spoken without knowledge. For he thought that the people of language said this, and no one from the people of language nor from the predecessors of the nation and its scholars said this..." (4).
Ibn al-Qayyim said: "And if it is known that the division of words into truth and metaphor is not a legal, nor rational, nor linguistic division, then it is purely a terminology. It is a terminology that occurred after the three favored centuries by text, and its origin was from the side of the Mu'tazila and Jahmiyyah and those who followed their path from the Theologians..." (5).

Topic Four: Interpretation (Ta'wil) or Relegation (Tafwid)
Since the source of receiving creed for the Maturidiyyah in Rationalities is the Intellect, which is a ruler and origin, and Revelation is subordinate to it and a branch of it; if Revelation comes contrary to Reason, it must be rejected or distorted by interpreting it and diverting it from its apparent meaning. As for Auditories (Sam'iyyat), the source of receiving creed for them is Revelation.
The Mutawatir (concurrent) reports - like the texts of the Holy Quran and Mutawatir Sunnah - they judged them that even if they are definitive in establishment (Thubut), they are speculative in indication (Dalalah); because they are verbal evidences and speculative appearances that do not yield certainty, and they contradict definitive rational proofs. Rational proofs are definitive demonstrations, and in case of conflict, rational proofs are prioritized because they are the origin (1).
Auditory evidences are either relegated (Tafwid) or interpreted (Ta'wil) (2). As for rational proofs, their interpretation is impossible (3).
They differed among themselves in which one to prioritize. Some of them said regarding these verses - meaning the verses of Informative Attributes - that they are ambiguous (Mutashabihat); we believe regarding them that there is no way to run them on their apparent meanings, nor do we occupy ourselves with their interpretation, and we believe that what Allah intended by them is true.
Others occupied themselves with explaining the probability of the verses having different meanings other than their apparent meaning. They say: We know that the intended meaning is some of what the words bear of meanings that are not contrary to Tawhid and Pre-eternity, and they do not decide definitively on Allah's intended meaning due to the lack of evidence necessitating decisiveness on the intended meaning and specifying some meanings (4).
He said in Al-Tamhid after mentioning the verses of attributes: "So either we believe in their revelation and do not occupy ourselves with their interpretation, or they are diverted to a face of interpretation that agrees with Tawhid" (5).

The saying of the Maturidiyyah and other Theologians regarding interpretation (Ta'wil) is manifestly corrupt. What indicates its corruption is their contradiction in it, and a contradictory saying is a corrupt saying. Therefore, the physician Ibn Al-Nafis used to say: There are only two schools: the school of Ahl al-Hadith or the school of Philosophers. As for these Theologians, their saying is manifestly contradictory and differing (1). By this he "means that Ahl al-Hadith affirmed everything the Messenger brought, while those [Theologians] made it all imagination and illusion. It is known by many auditory and rational proofs the corruption of the school of these heretics, so it is determined that the truth is the school of the Salaf, Ahl al-Hadith and Sunnah and Jama'ah" (2).
Therefore, they did not have a straight law in interpretation, so they cannot distinguish between texts that need interpretation and those that do not. They are, as Sheikh Al-Islam says: "They obligate interpretation in some Auditories but not others, and there is no one among those attributed to the Qibla, nor even others, who can interpret all Auditories. If it is so, it is said to them: What is the difference between what you permitted interpretation for and diverted from its apparent concept and clear meaning, and what you affirmed? They are between two matters: either they say what their majority says: That what is opposed by a definitive rational [proof] we interpret, and what is not opposed by a definitive rational [proof] we affirm. It is said to them: Then you cannot negate interpretation from anything; for you cannot negate all rational oppositions... Also, the absence of a definitive rational opponent does not necessitate certainty in the indication of the auditory evidence; for according to your saying, if you permit the Lawgiver to say a saying that has an understood meaning while He does not intend that, because in the subtle rationalities that do not occur to the minds of most people or do not occur to creation in many centuries there is what contradicts that, it is permissible that He intends by His speech what contradicts its implication without that [rational opponent], due to the possibility that in the Hereafter what contradicts that appears, or due to that not being known by rational evidence and the like. If it is permissible that people's believing Him in what He reported depends on such a condition, it is permissible that it depends on similar conditions, since all share in that dependence on such a condition necessitates not inferring from any of His reports knowledge of what He reported.

And if they say by interpreting everything except what is known by necessity that He intended it, that would be more far-reaching. For there is no text transmitted except that the one repelling it can say: It is not known by necessity that He intended this. If the affirmer can say: I know by necessity that He intended it, the one who affirms what disputes this affirmer in it can also say something similar... If you contemplate their speech, you will not find for them a law regarding what is interpreted and what is not interpreted. Rather, the implication of their saying is the possibility of interpreting everything... So it is known that their saying is false..." (1).
Then it is said to them: Saying by interpretation according to your terminology is worse than Likening (Tashbih) and Negation (Ta'til); for interpretation "implies Likening, Negation, manipulating texts, and thinking ill of them. For the Negator (Mu'attil) and the Interpreter (Mu'awwil) have shared in negating the realities of names and attributes, but the Interpreter distinguished himself by his manipulation of texts, violation of their sanctity, thinking ill of them, and attributing their Speaker to speaking what apparently is misguidance and misleading. So they combined four prohibitions: Their belief that the apparent meaning of the speech of Allah and His Messenger is impossible falsehood, so they understood Likening first, then moved to the second prohibition which is Negation, so they negated their realities based on that understanding which does not befit them nor befit the Lord, Majestic is His Majesty. The third prohibition is attributing the Speaker, who is Perfect in Knowledge, Perfect in Clarification, Complete in Advice, to the opposite of clarification, guidance, and direction... There is no doubt for every rational person that this implies they were more knowledgeable than Him, or more eloquent, or more advisory to people. The fourth prohibition: Their manipulation of texts and violation of their sanctities. If you saw them chewing them with their mouths while punishments have befallen them [the texts] and waves of interpretations have played with them, and the people of interpretation called out over them in the market of 'who increases', so each one offered in their price whatever interpretations he wanted. If you saw them among them while the Negators sat on their straight path pushing them back by their chests and rears, saying: You have no way over us, and if it must be, then by way of metaphor. For we are the people of rationalities and owners of demonstrations, and you are verbal evidences and auditory appearances that do not yield knowledge nor certainty. So there is no god but Allah and Allah is Greatest, how many strongholds of faith have been demolished by these pickaxes, and how many fortresses of the realities of Sunnah and Quran have been breached by them..." (2).

As for the saying of Relegation (Tafwid), it is among the worst sayings of the people of innovation; due to its contradiction and opposition to the texts of pondering the Quran, and its implication of attributing ignorance of the Lord of the Worlds to the Prophets and Messengers. For it is known "that Allah Almighty commanded us to ponder the Quran and urged us to reason and understand it. So how is it permissible with that, that it is intended from us to turn away from understanding, knowing, and reasoning it?! Also, the discourse which was intended for our guidance and clarification to us and bringing us out of darkness into light, if what is mentioned in it of texts its apparent meaning is falsehood and disbelief, and it was not intended from us to know neither its apparent nor its hidden meaning, or it was intended from us to know its hidden meaning without clarification in the discourse for that; then on both estimations we were not addressed with what clarifies the truth nor did we know that the indication of this discourse is falsehood and disbelief.
The reality of the saying of these people regarding the One addressing us is that He did not clarify the truth nor explain it while commanding us to believe it, and that what He addressed us with and commanded us to follow and refer to did not clarify the truth nor reveal it; rather its apparent meaning indicated disbelief and falsehood, and He wanted from us not to understand anything from it, or to understand from it what there is no evidence for in it. All of this is something known by necessity to be far removed from Allah and His Messenger, and it is of the genus of the sayings of the people of distortion and atheism" (1).
"So according to the saying of these people, the Prophets and Messengers do not know the meanings of what Allah revealed to them of these texts, nor do the Angels nor the early Predecessors. Then, what Allah described Himself with in the Quran, or much of what Allah described Himself with, the Prophets do not know its meaning; rather they say words whose meaning they do not reason... It is known that this is a defamation of the Quran and the Prophets; since Allah revealed the Quran and informed that He made it guidance and clarification for people, and commanded the Messenger to convey the clear notification and to clarify to people what was revealed to them, and commanded pondering the Quran and reasoning it. Yet, despite this, the most noble part of it, which is what the Lord reported about His attributes... no one knows its meaning, so it is not reasoned nor pondered, and the Messenger did not clarify to people what was revealed to them nor conveyed the clear notification. According to this estimation, every atheist and innovator says: The truth in the matter itself is what I knew by my opinion and intellect, and there is nothing in the texts that contradicts that; because those texts are problematic and ambiguous, and no one knows their meaning, and what no one knows the meaning of cannot be used as evidence..." (2).

Topic Five: The Saying of Rational Goodness and Badness (Tahsin and Taqbih)
The Maturidiyyah went to say rational goodness and badness, and that the intellect perceives the goodness and badness of things. They differed among themselves regarding deciding Allah's judgment in the action merely by the intellect perceiving goodness and badness in it. Their majority goes to say that Allah's judgment is decided in some actions but not others before the arrival of revelation, like Divinities and Prophethoods. As for Auditories and Laws, they are not perceived except by Hearing (Revelation).
Some of them went to say that the intellect does not judge with the rule of Allah Almighty in what it perceived of the goodness and badness of the action except after the arrival of the Sharia.
Ibn Al-Humam said: "The Hanafis entirely said the establishment of goodness and badness for the action in the way the Mu'tazila said it. Then they agreed on negating what the Mu'tazila built on establishing goodness and badness for the action, such as saying the obligation of the fittest (Al-Aslah), and the obligation of provision and reward for obedience and compensation for paining children and animals.
They differed: Is it known, considering the knowledge of their establishment in an action, the judgment of Allah in that action as an obligation? Professor Abu Mansur and the generality of the Sheikhs of Samarkand said: Yes, the obligation of faith in Allah and magnifying Him, and the prohibition of attributing what is heinous to Him, and confirming the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, which is the meaning of thanking the Benefactor.
The Imams of Bukhara among them said: No faith is obligatory nor disbelief prohibited before the Mission, as it is not impossible that the Creator does not command faith nor reward for it even if it is good, nor does He, Glory be to Him, forbid disbelief nor punish for it even if it is bad. The summary is that the absence of obligation is not rationally impossible since He, Glory be to Him, does not need obedience nor is harmed by disobedience" (1).
The Maturidiyyah's saying of rational goodness and badness goes back to the fact that reason for them is the origin of knowledge, so it was an origin for hearing, and was prioritized over it in case of conflict (2).

Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, clarified the correct view in the issue of Goodness and Badness, saying: "It has been established by discourse and wisdom obtained from laws three types:
First: That the action contains a benefit or corruption even if the Sharia did not report that, just as it is known that justice contains the benefit of the world, and injustice contains their corruption. This type is good and bad, and the badness of that may be known by reason and Sharia, not that it established for the action a quality that was not there; but it does not follow from the occurrence of this badness that its doer is punished in the Hereafter if a Sharia did not report that. This is what the extremists who say by Goodness and Badness erred in, for they said: Servants are punished for their bad actions even if a Messenger was not sent to them. This contradicts the text, the Almighty said: {And We would not punish until We sent a messenger} [Al-Isra: (15)], and He said {And never would your Lord have destroyed the cities until He had sent to their mother city a messenger reciting to them Our verses. And We would not destroy the cities except while their people were wrongdoers} [Al-Qasas: 59]. The texts indicating that Allah does not punish except after the Message are many, refuting those who said from the people of Goodness and Badness that creation is punished on earth without a Messenger sent to them.
Second: That the Lawgiver if He commands something it becomes good, and if He forbids something it becomes bad, and the action acquires the quality of goodness and badness by the address of the Lawgiver.
Third: That the Lawgiver commands something to test the servant whether he obeys Him or disobeys Him, and the intent is not the doing of the commanded thing, as He commanded Abraham to slaughter his son. When they submitted and he put him down upon his forehead, the purpose was achieved so He ransomed him with the slaughter. Likewise the Hadith of the leper, the bald, and the blind, when He sent to them someone asking them for charity. When the blind man responded "The angel said: Keep your wealth; you have only been tested, and Allah is pleased with you and angry with your two companions" (1). So wisdom originates from the command itself not from the commanded action itself. This type and the one before it were not understood by the Mu'tazila, and they claimed that goodness and badness only exist for what is described as such without the command of the Lawgiver. The Ash'aris claimed that the entire Sharia is from the section of testing, and that actions have no quality neither before Sharia nor by Sharia. As for the wise scholars and the majority, they affirmed the three types and that is the correct view" (2).

text:
Topic One: Knowledge of Allah is obligatory according to them by reason before the arrival of revelation
The Maturidiyyah went to say that knowledge of Allah is obligatory by reason before the arrival of revelation, and that the human bears responsibility for this knowledge before the sending of Prophets and Messengers and is not excused for abandoning it, rather he is punished for abandoning it (1). Some of them obliged knowledge of Allah Almighty by reason on the rational child (2). Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi said: "Whoever revelation did not reach while he is rational and did not know his Lord, is he excused or not? According to us, he is not excused and he must deduce that the world has a Maker" (3).
The truth and correct view in this issue is that knowledge of Allah is innate (Fitrah) in hearts, and was indicated also by Reason and Hearing. Whenever the matter required deducing it due to an obstacle of doubt or desire, that became obligatory. "The Quran indicates this; for it mentions rational proofs and evidences for Tawhid, and clarifies its goodness and the ugliness of Shirk rationally and innately, and commands Tawhid and forbids Shirk. For this reason, Allah Almighty struck parables which are rational proofs, and addressed servants with that as an address to those in whose minds and innate natures the goodness of Tawhid and its obligation and the ugliness of Shirk and its blame are established. The Quran is full of rational proofs indicating that, such as His saying: {Allah presents an example: a slave owned by quarreling partners and another belonging exclusively to one man - are they equal in comparison? Praise be to Allah! But most of them do not know.} [Az-Zumar: 29], and His saying: {Allah presents an example: a slave who is owned and unable to do a thing and he to whom We have provided from Us good provision, so he spends from it secretly and publicly. Can they be equal? Praise to Allah! But most of them do not know.} [An-Nahl: 75], and His saying: {O people, an example is presented, so listen to it. Indeed, those you invoke besides Allah will never create [as much as] a fly, even if they gathered together for it. And if the fly should steal away from them a [tiny] thing, they could not recover it from him. Weak are the pursuer and pursued. They have not appraised Allah with true appraisal. Indeed, Allah is Powerful and Exalted in Might.} [Al-Hajj: 73 - 74] to multiples of that of rational proofs of Tawhid which the Quran guided to and alerted to.
But here is another matter which is that punishment for abandoning this obligation is delayed until the arrival of the Sharia as indicated by His saying Almighty: {And We would not punish until We sent a messenger} [Al-Isra: (15)], and His saying: {It almost bursts with rage. Every time a company is thrown into it, its keepers ask them, "Did there not come to you a warner?" (8) They say, "Yes, a warner had come to us, but we denied and said, 'Allah has not sent down anything. You are not but in great error.'"} [Al-Mulk: 8 - 9]. This is frequent in the Quran informing that the argument was established against them by His Book and His Messenger just as He alerted them by what is in their minds and innate natures of the goodness of Tawhid and gratitude and the ugliness of Shirk and Kufr" (4).

Topic Two: Ruling on the Faith of the Imitator (Muqallid)
When the Maturidiyyah said the obligation of observation (Nazar) and deduction (Istidlal) to know Allah, their majority went to say that whoever believed and did not observe and deduce, his faith is valid, but he sins for his abandoning observation and deduction. Some of them went to say that he is an imitator and does not sin for his abandoning observation and deduction.
Al-Nasiri said: "Imam Sayf al-Haqq Abu Al-Mu'in said: Then the school is that the imitator who has no proof is a believer, and the ruling of Islam is binding on him, and he is obedient to Allah Almighty in his belief and all other obediences, even if he is disobedient by abandoning observation and deduction, and his ruling is the ruling of others from the sinners of the people of the religion" (1).
Al-Zarnuji said: "For the faith of the imitator, even if it is valid according to us, he is sinful by abandoning deduction" (2).
The correct view in this issue is that decisiveness is sufficient in what decisiveness is required, even via imitation; for belief in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, and the Last Day: this is what decisiveness is required in, but the layman does not perceive that by its proof, yet we validate his faith, and say he is a believer even if he does not perceive that by its proof. The evidence for that is that Allah referred to asking the people of knowledge in an issue of religion where decisiveness is required, saying: {And We sent not before you except men to whom We revealed [Our message]. So ask the people of the message if you do not know} [Al-Anbiya: 7]; and it is clear that we ask them to take their saying, and it is known that belief that Messengers are men is from creed, yet Allah referred us in it to the people of knowledge... Moreover, if we obliged the layman to abandon imitation and adhere to taking by Ijtihad, we would oblige him with what he cannot bear, and Allah Almighty has said: {Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity} [Al-Baqarah: 286], and He said: {It is those who hasten to good deeds, and they outstrip [others] therein * And We do not charge any soul except [with that within] its capacity} [Al-Mu'minun: 61 - 62] (3).
Among what refutes those claiming the invalidity of the imitator's faith is that the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them all, conquered most of the non-Arab lands, and accepted the faith of their commoners, like the uncouth Arabs, even if it was under the sword, or following a leader of theirs who embraced Islam, and they did not order anyone of them to repeat observation, nor asked him for the proof of his confirmation, nor postponed his affair until he observes" (4).
Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said in his explanation of the Prophet's saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (I have been commanded to fight the people until they testify that there is no god but Allah...) (5): "In it is apparent indication for the school of the verifiers and the majorities of the Salaf and Khalaf that if a person believes with a decisive belief in which there is no hesitation, that suffices him, and he is a believer from the monotheists. It is not obligatory on him to learn the proofs of the theologians and know Allah Almighty by them, contrary to those who obliged that and made it a condition for being from the people of the Qibla and claimed that he does not have the ruling of Muslims except by it. This school is the saying of many of the Mu'tazila and some of our companions the theologians, and it is an apparent error; for the intent is decisive confirmation and it has occurred; and because the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, sufficed with confirmation of what he came with, peace and blessings be upon him, and did not stipulate knowledge by proof. Hadiths in the two Sahihs have demonstrated this, collectively yielding Tawatur in their principle and definitive knowledge" (6).

Topic Three: Tawhid of Lordship (Rububiyyah)
The intended meaning of Tawhid according to the Maturidiyyah is the belief in Oneness (Wahdaniyyah), which for them is a negative attribute spoken of in three types:
First: Oneness in Essence (Dhat). They mean by it the negation of plurality from His Essence Almighty, meaning it does not accept division. So they say He is One in His Essence having no partner/divider. They interpreted the word Al-Ahad mentioned in the texts regarding Allah Almighty with this meaning. So they said in interpreting the Almighty's saying: {Say, "He is Allah, [who is] One} [Al-Ikhlas: (1)] He is Allah One, meaning the Existing One who has no part and no division to His Essence (1).
Second: Oneness in Attributes. What is meant by it, as they say: Negation of a peer to Him Almighty in every attribute of His attributes. So it is impossible that He Almighty has multiple knowledges and powers according to the knowns and empowered things; rather His knowledge Almighty is one, and His knowns are many, and His power is one, and His empowered things are many, and this applies to all His attributes.
They intended by them - meaning the previous two types - negating Anthropomorphism (Tajsim) and Likening (Tashbih), and they included in the name of this Tawhid which they coined the negation of what they negate of the attributes established by the Book and Sunnah. Therefore, they made negating body (Jism), substance (Jawhar), accident ('Arad) and similar invented words and meanings among the principles of their creed (2).
Third: Oneness in Actions. It is called Tawhid of Actions. The intended meaning is His singling out Almighty in inventing all beings generally and the impossibility of attributing influence to other than Him Almighty in anything of the possible things at all.
The summary of their saying in His Tawhid Almighty: That He is One in His Essence having no divider or part, One in His attributes having no like, and One in His actions having no partner (3).

text:
Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi said in explaining the meaning of the One and Tawhid: "And Allah is One, He has no like, Eternal, Subsisting, having no opposite nor peer. This is the interpretation of His saying: {There is nothing like unto Him} [Al-Shura: 11]. And One by being unique from likes and opposites. Therefore, the saying of body and accident regarding Him is void as they are interpretations of things. If this is established, estimating all that is attributed to Him of creation and described by Him of attributes with what is understood if it were attributed to creation and described by it becomes void" (1).
Tawhid is singling out Allah Almighty with what He deserves of Lordship, Divinity, and Names and Attributes. It is divided into three sections: Tawhid of Lordship, Tawhid of Divinity, and Tawhid of Names and Attributes. Or into two sections: Tawhid of Knowledge and Affirmation: which is Tawhid of Lordship and Tawhid of Names and Attributes, and Tawhid of Intent and Will and Demand: which is Tawhid of Divinity (2). This is the creed of Muslims, believers in the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him.
The intended meaning of Tawhid of Lordship: Firm belief that Allah alone is the Creator, Provider, Giver of Life, Causer of Death, Disposer of all His creation's affairs, He has no partner in that (3).
The intended meaning of Tawhid of Divinity (4): Singling out Allah alone with submission, humility, love, reverence, and all types of worship, He has no partner.
The intended meaning of Tawhid of Names and Attributes: Firm belief in Allah's names and attributes mentioned in the Book and Sunnah, and affirming them without distortion, negation, conditioning, or likening (5).

The Maturidiyyah believe that knowledge of Allah is not accomplished by necessary innate knowledge; rather it is only by rational acquisition. Therefore, one of the principles upon which their creed is built is (the obligation of knowing Allah by reason) and they arranged upon that the obligation of observation and deduction and made it the first duty on the servant (1). They made it the great goal and the supreme purpose, and that whoever brings it is a believing monotheist.
Their establishment of Tawhid of Lordship is based on proving two issues:
First: Proving the existence of Allah: The Maturidiyyah believe that Allah Almighty is not known except through the world. In this regard, Al-Maturidi says: "The principle is that Allah Almighty, since there is no way to know Him except through the indication of the world to Him, by the cutting off of ways to reach knowledge of Him through senses or the testimony of hearing" (2). This knowledge for them is by proving the temporal origination (Huduth) of the world, then inferring by that the existence of its Originator Almighty (3).
Second: Proving the Oneness of Allah Almighty in His Lordship: The Maturidiyyah inferred the Oneness of Allah Almighty in His Lordship by the famous proof among Theologians known as the Proof of Mutual Prevention (Dalil Al-Tamanu') (4).
The form of the Proof of Mutual Prevention for them is: "If it is proven that the world has an originator who originated it and a maker who made it, the Maker must be one. For if it had two makers, mutual prevention would be established between them, and that is proof of their temporal origination, or the temporal origination of one of them. For if one of them wanted to create life in a person and the other wanted to create death in him - and likewise in all opposites like movement and rest, gathering and separation, blackness and whiteness, etc. - either their wills are achieved and opposites exist in the locus which is impossible, or their wills are disabled and not executed and neither this nor that happens in the locus which is incapacitating them both, or the will of one of them is executed without the other and in it is the incapacitation of the one whose will was not executed. And incapacity is one of the signs of temporal origination. So if proving two eternal makers for the world is not conceivable, the Maker was necessarily one" (5).

This proof is a correct proof and a complete demonstration for proving the impossibility of the world emanating from two (1). However, the belief of the Maturidiyyah that this proof is what is intended by the Almighty's saying: {Had there been within the heavens and earth gods besides Allah, they both would have been ruined} [Al-Anbiya: 22], is a false belief and incorrect understanding of the word of Allah. What made them say this is their belief that Al-Ilah (God) means Al-Alih (Capable) - active participle - and that Divinity (Ilahiyyah) is the ability to invent (2). So Al-Ilah for them means Al-Rabb (Lord), and the verse indicated the negation of two Lords only, by estimating the impossibility of action from two Lords. So the verse for them indicated the negation of Shirk in Lordship only, which is the requirement of the Proof of Mutual Prevention. While the verse "indicated what is more perfect and greater than this, and that proving two Lords for the world was not held by anyone from the sons of Adam. But the Shirk that occurred in the world only occurred by making some creatures created for other than Allah, and in Divinity by worshipping other than Allah Almighty, and taking intermediaries and invoking them and drawing near to them. As for proving two equal creators for the world, no one from humans went to that. Allah Almighty has said: {And if you asked them, "Who created the heavens and earth?" they would surely say, "Allah."} [Az-Zumar: (38)]. Based on this, there is a big difference between the requirement of the verse and the requirement of the Proof of Mutual Prevention - according to the Maturidiyyah. The requirement of the verse is proving Tawhid of Divinity by the corruption of the world if there existed anyone deserving worship with Allah other than Allah Almighty, while the requirement of the Proof of Mutual Prevention is proving Tawhid of Lordship by the corruption of the world if another creator existed for the world.
The Maturidiyyah also inferred with other proofs such as inferring by the finiteness of the world, the signs of Prophets and Messengers, the consistency of the world and precision of its making. Al-Maturidi stated this in the book (Al-Tawhid) saying: "And the indication that the Originator of the world is One, is the agreement of the saying that One is a name for the beginning of number and a name for greatness, authority, elevation, and virtue, as it is said so-and-so is the unique one of his time, and peerless in elevation, virtue, and majesty. And what exceeds that does not bear other than number, so the world must be finite since if there was one thing of them, the whole would exit finiteness by the exit of originators and that is far-fetched. Then there is no number pointed to except that it is possible to claim increase on it and decrease from it; so saying by something was not necessary because there is no reality for that by the right of number in which others do not share, therefore the saying by it is void" (3).
He said in his inference by the signs of Prophets and Messengers and the consistency of the world: "It was not mentioned about other than the God whom the people of Tawhid know, a claim of Divinity and pointing to a trace of action from him indicating his Lordship. Nor was there found in anything a meaning possible to extract from its bearing. Nor did he send messengers with signs that conquer minds and dazzle them to prove that the saying of that is imagination and whispering. And the coming of Messengers with signs which he who witnessed them is compelled [to admit] that they are the action of one who, if he had a partner, would prevent them from showing them since in that is invalidation of their Lordship and Divinity. So if he is not found nor were they prevented from that despite the abundance of those arrogant against them and stubborn opponents among those who, if they loved the existence of sight for them in showing their signs, they would have found it; so it is proven that that was only surrendered to the Messengers because the True God and Creator of creation is none other than the One, the Subduer who subdued every stubborn arrogant one from camouflage let alone verification" (4).

Topic Four: Tawhid of Divinity (Uluhiyyah)
The Maturidiyyah did not address Tawhid of Divinity, nor did any of them pay attention to it; even though it is the origin of religion, and the beginning and end of the call of the Prophets and Messengers. This Tawhid is what the Messengers brought and called their people to. The Messengers affirm Tawhid of Lordship and call to Tawhid of Divinity as Allah informed about them (1). Allah Almighty said: {And We sent not before you any messenger except that We revealed to him that, "There is no deity except Me, so worship Me"} [Al-Anbiya: 25]. And He Almighty said about Noah, peace be upon him: {And We had certainly sent Noah to his people, [saying], "Indeed, I am to you a clear warner (25) That you not worship except Allah. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a painful day (26)} [Hud: 25 - 26]. And He Almighty said about Hud, peace be upon him: {And to 'Aad [We sent] their brother Hud. He said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. You are not but inventors [of falsehood]"} [Hud: 50] (2).
They did not differentiate between Tawhid of Divinity and Tawhid of Lordship; rather, they confused the meaning of Divinity with the meaning of Lordship. They thought that the meaning of Divinity is the ability to invent. Thus, they believed that Tawhid of Lordship is what is intended in His saying Almighty: {Had there been within the heavens and earth gods besides Allah, they both would have been ruined} [Al-Anbiya: (22)], and similar verses. They thought that the intended meaning of Tawhid - which is Allah's right upon His servants - is merely Tawhid of Lordship, which is the belief that Allah alone created the world. They thought that if they proved that by evidence, they had proved the ultimate Tawhid and that whoever came with it had purified the religion entirely for Allah and became a believing monotheist (3).
Therefore, their attention was on Tawhid of Attributes and Tawhid of Actions - Tawhid of Lordship - (4). As for Tawhid of Actions: it is the most famous type of Tawhid for them, which is Tawhid of Lordship and Creatorship, meaning "that Allah is the Creator of the world alone, and they think that this is the required Tawhid, and the goal, and that it is the meaning of 'La ilaha illa Allah'? Since they interpreted 'Divinity' as 'Ability to invent'" (5).

Topic Five: Tawhid of Names and Attributes
The intended meaning of Tawhid of Names and Attributes is: Firm belief in Allah's names and attributes mentioned in the Book and Sunnah, and affirming them without distortion, negation, conditioning, or likening (1).
"The principle in this chapter is that Allah is described with what He described Himself with and what His Messengers described Him with, negation and affirmation. So we affirm for Allah what He affirmed for Himself and negate from Him what He negated from Himself. It is known that the method of the predecessors of the nation and its Imams is: affirming what He affirmed of attributes without conditioning or likening, and without distortion or negation. Likewise, they negate from Him what He negated from Himself while affirming what He affirmed of attributes without deviation (Ilhad) neither in His names nor in His verses. For Allah Almighty dispraised those who deviate in His names and verses, as He Almighty said: {And to Allah belong the best names, so invoke Him by them. And leave [the company of] those who practice deviation concerning His names. They will be recompensed for what they have been doing} [Al-A'raf: 180], and He Almighty said: {Indeed, those who inject deviation into Our verses are not concealed from Us. So, is he who is cast into the Fire better or he who comes secure on the Day of Resurrection? Do whatever you will; indeed, He is Seeing of what you do (40)} [Fussilat: 40]. So their method includes affirming Names and Attributes while negating likeness to creatures: affirmation without likening and transcendence without negation, as He Almighty said: {There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the Hearing, the Seeing} [Al-Shura: 11]. In His saying: {There is nothing like unto Him} is a refutation of Likening (Tashbih) and Representation (Tamthil), and in His saying: {and He is the Hearing, the Seeing} is a refutation of Deviation and Negation" (2).
"If you know that Tawhid of Names and Attributes is to call upon Allah Almighty with what He named Himself and describe Him with what He described Himself and His Messenger Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, described Him, and negate Likening and Representation from Him, then the opposite of that is several things (3):
First: Denying any of the Names or what they indicate of attributes and rulings, as the people of Negation (Ta'til) did.
Second: Naming Allah Almighty with what He did not name Himself; because the names of Allah Almighty are Tawqifiyyah (restricted to revelation); so naming Allah Almighty with what He did not name Himself is deviating with them from what is obligatory regarding them.
Third: Believing that these names indicate the descriptions of creatures, making them indicate Representation.
Fourth: Deriving names for idols from the names of Allah Almighty, as the polytheists did in deriving Al-Uzza from Al-Aziz, and deriving Al-Lat from Al-Ilah.
Fifth: Divesting Allah of His attributes of perfection and descriptions of majesty, or likening His attributes to the attributes of His creation. Allah Almighty has said: {There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the Hearing, the Seeing} [Al-Shura: 11], and He Almighty said: {He knows what is [presently] before them and what will be after them, but they do not encompass it in knowledge (110)} [Taha: 110]" (4).

First: Tawhid of Names:
The Maturidiyyah said the obligation of affirming Allah Almighty's names, and that affirming them does not entail Likening (Tashbih), evidenced by the fact that Messengers and Divine Books came with them. If affirming them contained Likening, that would be an attack on the Messengers. Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi said: "The principle according to us is that Allah has essential names by which He is named, such as His saying: {The Most Merciful} [Al-Rahman: 1]. Then the evidence for what we said is the coming of Messengers and Divine Books with them. If naming with what the Messengers brought contained Likening, they would be a cause for breaking Tawhid. But since those names bore the exit of the One named by them from the known named ones by the permissibility of their coming with them along with His saying: {There is nothing like unto Him} [Al-Shura: (11)] to negate by it the thingness of things" (1).
Their majority went to say Tawqif (restriction to revelation) in Allah's names, meaning the way to affirm names is Hearing (Revelation), so Allah is not named except with what He named Himself and the Sharia brought.
Al-Maturidi said - in his negation of the name 'Body' (Jism) for Allah -: "Its right is Hearing from Allah, that Body is not among His names, and it was not reported from Him nor from anyone whom He permitted anyone to imitate. So saying it is not permissible. If it were permissible by coining without sensory, auditory, or rational evidence, it would be permissible to say Body (Jasad) and Person (Shakhs), and all that is denounced by Hearing. And not everything creatures are named with is said [of Him], and that is corrupt" (2).
What pushed them to say that Allah's names are Tawqifiyyah - even though their source of reception is Reason - is the fear of applying names to Allah Almighty that imply attributing imperfection to Him, Glory be to Him. So they said Tawqif out of precaution as stated by the author of (Bayan Al-I'tiqad) saying: "The truth is that Tawqif is necessary as a precaution against what implies falsehood due to the greatness of danger in that. It is not permissible to suffice regarding the non-implication of falsehood with the reach of our perception, but one must rely on the permission of the Sharia" (3).
Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi said: "It is not permissible to say to Allah Almighty 'O Blessed' (Ya Mubarak). Because this is not known in His names by transmission, and we must remain silent about naming Him with what He did not name Himself" (4).

Then the Maturidiyyah in their affirmation of Names did not differentiate between the chapter of Informing about Allah Almighty and the chapter of Naming. So they included in His names Almighty what is not among His names such as the Maker (Al-Sani'), the Eternal (Al-Qadim), the Essence (Al-Dhat), the Thing (Al-Shay'), and similar. He said in proving the permissibility of applying the word (Thing) to Allah, and that it is among His names, inferring for that by His saying Almighty: {There is nothing like unto Him} [Al-Shura: (11)], and His saying Almighty: {Say, "What thing is greatest in testimony?" Say, "Allah is witness between me and you."} [Al-An'am: (19)]: "And after, saying all this is obligatory because naming by it is established in Hearing" (1).
As for their affirmation of the meanings of Names, they either make the meaning of the Name the Essence, and this is in the name (Allah) only. Or the meaning is taken by them considering the attributes they affirmed, such as the name Hearing (Al-Sami'), Seeing (Al-Basir), and Knowing (Al-Alim). Or they return it to negative and relative attributes.
So if the Name indicates what they affirmed of attributes, they affirmed it on its reality. And if it contradicts, they diverted it from its reality by interpretation; due to their belief that what the Name indicates of meanings and realities contradicts rational evidence. Ibn Al-Humam said: "Then He Almighty is Hearing by a hearing, and Seeing by an attribute called sight, and likewise Knowing by knowledge, Powerful by power, and Willing by will because He Almighty applied these names to Himself in an address to one who is of the people of language. The concept in language of 'Knowing' is an essence that has knowledge; rather, it is impossible for them 'Knowing' without knowledge like its impossibility without a known object. So it is not permissible to divert it from it except for a rational definitive proof necessitating its negation" (2).
Al-Bayadi said: "The concept of the Name may be the Essence itself and reality, which is the Name of Majesty only. And it may be taken considering attributes, actions, negations, and relations. There is no hiddenness in the multiplicity of His names Almighty by this consideration" (3).
As for the rest of the names, the Maturidiyyah acknowledges that they have meanings taken considering attributes, i.e., they indicate attributes just as they indicate the Essence. However, in names whose meanings do not agree with what they believed in the chapter of attributes, they do not affirm what they indicated of meanings and realities in the correct manner; rather, they interpret them with what agrees with their belief in attributes.

Among the examples of that is the name of Allah (Al-A'la - The Most High): Al-Maturidi said in his interpretation of the name (Al-A'la): "Al-A'la. He is higher than to be touched by need or attached by affliction" (1). In summary, their doctrine regarding the Beautiful Names is of two types:
First: What included truth and agreed with Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah in its appearance, including:
1 - Affirming all of Allah's Beautiful Names for Him Almighty, thus separating from the extremist Jahmiyyah who do not affirm names for Allah (3).
2 - Affirming many meanings of Allah Almighty's names, thus separating from the Jahmiyyah of Mu'tazila, because they affirm names stripped of meanings (4).
3 - Allah Almighty's names are Tawqifiyyah, so it is not permissible to name Allah Almighty except with what came in the Sharia (5).
4 - Allah Almighty's names are all beautiful (Husna), and they are not words stripped of their meanings, but indicate good meanings of glorification, sanctification, and magnification (6). His names Almighty are the best names and most majestic, for informing about the best meanings and most noble ones and for indicating attributes of perfection of Majesty, Beauty, and Honor (7).
Second: What included falsehood and deviation: The most important of which are:
1 - That Allah Almighty's names are not real names for Allah Almighty. Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi said: "It indicates to you that the names we call Him by are expressions of what brings closer to understandings, not that they are in reality His names" (8).
2 - The Beautiful Names do not contain independent attributes but are included in the attribute of Takwin (Bringing into being). Anwar Shah Al-Kashmiri Al-Deobandi said: "The Beautiful Names according to the Ash'aris are expressions of relations, and as for the Maturidiyyah, they are all included in the attribute of Takwin" (9).
3 - Allah's Beautiful Names are created according to them: Because they are expressions of words and letters, and they are created. Therefore, they made Allah Almighty's Beautiful Names 'Tasmiyat' (namings).

When they said they are namings, they said: They are other than Allah Almighty, they are letters and words, and the Eternal Name is the Named Himself, which is Allah, none other (1). All this to graduate to saying that Allah Almighty's names are created after their saying: They are other than Allah; because everything other than Allah is created (2).
One of the most important issues related to the chapter of Names for the Maturidiyyah is the issue: The Name and the Named. The Maturidiyyah went in this issue to say that the Name is the Named. They argued with His saying Almighty: {Blessed is the name of your Lord} [Al-Rahman: (78)], and His saying: {Exalt the name of your Lord, the Most High} [Al-A'la: (1)]. They said: Allah is the Creator and what is other than Him is created, so if His names were other than Him, they would be created, and it would imply that He has no name in pre-eternity nor attribute (3).
Al-Bazdawi said: "The proof compels us and every rational person to say that the Name is the Named itself, for people were commanded to worship Allah Almighty, and unify Allah Almighty, magnify Him, takbir Him, and tahlil Him. If the Name were other than the Named, this would be a mistake. Allah Almighty said: {And worship Allah and associate nothing with Him} [An-Nisa: 36], and He said: {O mankind, fear your Lord} [Al-Hajj: (1)]" (4).
Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi said: "Know that the Name and the Named are one. And Allah Almighty with all His names is One. Our evidence is the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic: {So worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion} [Az-Zumar: (2)], and His saying Almighty: {And they were not commanded except to worship one God} [At-Tawbah: (31)]. Allah Almighty commanded us to unify Allah Almighty, so if the name of Allah Almighty were other than Allah, the occurrence of Tawhid would be for the Name not for Allah Almighty" (5).
The correct view in the issue is detailing: "So the Name is intended by it the Named sometimes, and intended by it the word indicating it other times. If you say: Allah said such, and Allah rose over His Throne, and Allah heard, saw and created, then what is intended here is the Named Himself. And if you say (Allah) is an Arabic name, and (Al-Rahman) is an Arabic name, and (Al-Rahman) is from the names of Allah, and (Al-Rahman) its weight is Fa'lan, and (Al-Rahman) is derived from Rahma and similar, then the Name here is for the Named and it is not said 'other' due to the ambiguity in the word 'other'. If the difference meant is that the word is other than the meaning, then it is true. And if it is meant that Allah, Glory be to Him, was without a name until He created for Himself a name or until His creation named Him with names of their making, then this is of the greatest deviation and atheism" (6).

Second: Tawhid of Attributes:
The Maturidiyyah are considered among the Sifatiyyah (Attributists) regarding Allah Almighty's attributes, because they affirm some attributes, and affirm for these attributes a real meaning subsisting in the Essence of the Lord Almighty. They are not merely the description of the describer or negation of the opposite according to them (1). The Maturidiyyah emphasized that affirming these attributes does not entail Likening (Tashbih), since there is no similarity between the reality of the Creator and the created. If affirming attributes entailed Likening, it would imply pre-eternity of the created or temporal origination of the Creator, which no rational person says. Al-Maturidi said: "There is no likeness in affirming Names and verifying Attributes to negate the realities of what is in creation from Him. For if He had similarity to anything, pre-eternity would fall from Him due to that, or temporal origination would fall from the other. If He were described by similarity to other than Him in any aspect, He would become from that aspect like one of creation" (2).
The affirmative attributes according to the Maturidiyyah are eight attributes: Power (Qudra), Knowledge (Ilm), Life (Hayat), Will (Irada), Hearing (Sam'), Sight (Basar), Speech (Kalam), and Bringing into Being (Takwin) (3). They singled out affirmation for these attributes over others, because they are the ones indicated by reason according to them. As for other attributes, there is no evidence for them from reason according to them, so they said by negating them.
They followed two methods in inferring the affirmation of these attributes, and sometimes they may follow other methods:
First: Transcending imperfections.
Second: Indication of created things.
Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi clarified the first method saying: "If it is proven that the Maker of the world is Eternal, and from the condition of Eternity is freedom from imperfections, it is proven that He is Living, Capable, Hearing, Seeing, Knowing. For if He were not so, He would be described with death, ignorance, incapacity, blindness, and deafness, since these attributes are successive to those attributes. If these attributes were not established for Allah Almighty, what succeeds them would be established, which are attributes of deficiency, and from the condition of Eternity is Perfection. So it indicated that He is described with what we explained due to the necessity of negating their opposites which are marks of the temporal due to being deficiencies" (4).

He said regarding the second method: "And if it is also proven that He is the Inventor of this world with its different types, and He is its Creator as it is of precision and mastery, novel description, wondrous organization and arrangement, composition of orbits and what is in them of moving stars, and what is seen of wonders in the bodies of animals of life, distinction, and guidance to attracting benefits and repelling harms, and what is in them of senses, and what is in inanimate bodies of wonders and properties deposited in them such that if a person of insight described with precise thought, sharp mind, superior intellect, perfect intelligence, and strong discrimination contemplated all his life in them he would not grasp their essence; rather not a part of a thousand parts of what is in them of traces of perfect wisdom and subtle management, it is proven that He is Living, Capable, Knowing, Hearing, Seeing. Knowledge of that runs the course of intuitive axioms, so much so that all rational people attribute one who attributes weaving embroidered brocade, producing elegant images, building high palaces, and making sailing ships to a dead, incapable, ignorant person, either to foolishness and stupidity, or to stubbornness and arrogance" (1).
Also, regarding the attributes they did not affirm, they followed: either Relegation (Tafwid), or Interpretation (Ta'wil). They said: If we left these texts on their apparent meaning without relegation or interpretation, and affirmed what they indicate as a real indication and did not divert them to metaphorical meanings, Likening (Tashbih) would follow from that. This contradicts Transcendence (Tanzih); because reason deems impossible what the apparent meanings of these texts indicate, and they are speculative appearances in opposition to definitive rational demonstrations, so we prioritize rational demonstrations over them. These speculative appearances, either we relegate their meanings to Allah Almighty as the Salaf did - according to their claim (2), or we interpret them with types of metaphors to meanings that agree with rational demonstrations (3).
They claim that carrying these texts on their apparent meaning is deemed impossible by reason, so they are either relegated in their meanings or interpreted. So first: they fell into Likening, second: they fled from it, third: they distorted the texts, fourth: they negated the attributes, and fifth: they fell into what they fled from of Likening and Representation, rather worse than it where they described Allah with attributes of the nonexistent, rather the impossible (4).
