And sixth: They fell into contradiction and inconsistency; as they affirmed some attributes and negated some with this doubt, even though that doubt exists in what they affirmed of attributes since there is no difference between what they affirmed and what they negated (1).
Thus, the Maturidi doctrine regarding the attributes of Allah Almighty is summarized as follows:
1 - They affirmed some of Allah Almighty's affirmative essential attributes, like His Life, Knowledge, Power, and Will, Glory be to Him and Most High.
2 - Their majority also affirmed His Hearing Almighty and His Sight, Glory be to Him (2).
3 - As for negative attributes, they affirmed them with deviation and negation which they fell into.
4 - They affirmed the attribute of Takwin (Bringing into being) considering it a reference for active attributes. The intended meaning of Takwin is active attributes: which are what returns to Takwin of attributes like creating, providing, giving life, and causing death. So the attribute of Takwin is that He, Glory be to Him, brings things into being, so He creates, forms, heals, gives life, and causes death by His saying 'Be and it is', and it is called the attribute of Creation or Action (3). According to them, the Action is other than the Object of action, and Takwin is other than the Mukawwan (thing brought into being). Therefore, they say by the pre-eternity of Allah Almighty's attributes of action like creation, giving life, and provision, even if the object of these is temporal (4).
5 - They inferred for affirming the attributes they affirmed with texts from the Book and Sunnah (5).
6 - Their restriction of Allah Almighty's attributes. They restricted all attributes to twenty-one attributes only. Some of them explicitly restricted the affirmative essential attributes to seven, and the eighth attribute is Takwin, which is an active attribute. He said: "And according to the illustrious successors, it does not exceed eight attributes, and other attributes return to them" (6). Also, Shah Muhammad Anwar Al-Kashmiri, one of the senior Deobandi Imams (1352 AH), explicitly stated that the Beautiful Names are all included in the attribute of Takwin (7).

So where do they place the name of Majesty "Allah" and similar Beautiful Names that indicate the Essence of Allah Almighty and the essential affirmative attributes of perfection? Do they place them also in the attribute of Takwin?
When they said by restricting Divine attributes to what they mentioned, they negated all other attributes of Allah's perfection, and distorted their explicit, firm, authentic texts. And with their affirmation of these attributes, they almost negated and stripped them, for they explicitly stated that each of these attributes is a single pre-eternal attribute with no multiplicity or renewal in it, but renewal is in its attached objects; because that is more fitting for the perfection of Tawhid (1). 7 - They negated the attribute of Speech: which is Allah Almighty's speech heard with letter and voice, and He has not ceased and does not cease to speak.
8 - They said the innovation of Psychological Speech (Kalam Nafsi), and some of them explicitly stated there is no difference between them and the Mu'tazila in saying the creation of the Quran (2).
9 - They do not affirm active attributes and do not say they subsist in Allah Almighty. It is known that an attribute is not an attribute unless it subsists in the described and the described is characterized by it. As they said: "It is known that each of that - meaning the attributes they affirmed - indicates a meaning additional to the concept of the Necessary. Not all are synonymous words, and the truth of the derivative on the thing necessitates the establishment of the source of derivation for it, so the attribute of Knowledge, Power, Life, etc. is established for Him, not as the Mu'tazila claim: that He is Knowing with no knowledge, and Capable with no power etc., for it is an obvious impossibility like our saying: black with no blackness. Texts have spoken of the establishment of His knowledge, power, and others". And they said: "And it has no meaning other than He is described with Speech" (3). And they returned all active attributes to the attribute of Takwin, and that all active attributes are not real attributes of Allah Almighty, but rather they are from the attachments of the attribute of Takwin, and Takwin is a pre-eternal attribute which is for them: the principle of bringing out from non-existence to existence.

Topic One: Belief in Messengers
Section One: How Prophethood is proven
The Maturidiyyah believe that proving the truthfulness of Messengers and Prophets is based on observing the physical and moral attributes of Prophets before and after the Message, and on Allah's support for them with miracles indicating their truthfulness.
Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi said: "Then the principle according to us in informing of Messengers is two aspects:
First: The appearance of their states in a way that reason repels doubt from them, and refuses imagining suspicion in them due to accompanying them in childhood and old age, finding them pure, chosen, pious among a people where equality among them on that is not possible, nor does their upbringing reach that, upon the appearance of their states to them, and their being among them in residence and spread. So it is known with encompassing that this is preservation from One who knows that He sets them in a noble station, and makes them trustees over the unseen and secrets. This is what nature inclines to accept and reason approves all their affairs, so the one rejecting it rejects after knowledge a rejection of obstinacy.
Second: The coming of signs (miracles) outside the natures of the people of insight in that type, impossible to aspire to the like of or reach its essence by learning, with what if it were possible for someone to reach that by learning and diligence, since the Messengers did not grow up in that nor were raised by it, it appears that they benefited it by Allah honoring them with it to make them trustees over His revelation" (1).
As for the majority of Maturidiyyah, they see that there is no proof for the truthfulness of the Prophet other than the miracle, arguing that the miracle alone yields certain knowledge of the establishment of the prophethood of the Prophet or Messenger.
Al-Bazdawi said: "It is not conceivable to establish the Message without proof, so establishment is by proofs; and those proofs are nothing but miracles. So the message of every Messenger was established by miracles appearing at his hands... So miracles were the proof of the truthfulness of their claim of the Message; for what appeared is not within human capacity, so it is known that Allah is the Originator. He only originates them to be a proof of the truthfulness of his claim; for the people of every Messenger asked him for proofs of his truthfulness, so he supplicated to Allah Almighty to support him by giving what they asked of him. When He gave him the proof of his truthfulness which his people asked of him, that became proof of his truthfulness from Allah Almighty, for Allah does not support the liar. And people must know the Messengers and there is no way to knowledge except miracles" (2).

There is no doubt that miracles are a correct proof for establishing the prophethood of Prophets; but saying that the prophethood of Prophets is not known except by miracles is an incorrect saying. Rather, there are other proofs, including what appears on him of knowledge, truthfulness, righteousness, and types of good deeds appearing to anyone with the slightest discrimination, and what accompanies him of states and other things (1). No one has claimed Prophethood among the liars except that there appeared on him of ignorance, lying, wickedness, and Satan's overpowering him what appeared of his state upon the slightest discrimination, and people distinguish between the truthful and the liar.
For this reason, since Khadijah, may Allah be pleased with her, knew from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he is the Truthful, the Righteous, she said to him when the Revelation came to him: (I feared for myself), she said: Nay, by Allah, Allah will never disgrace you. You join ties of kinship, speak the truth, bear the burden of the weak, host the guest, earn for the destitute, and help in the vicissitudes of truth" (2) (10).
So he did not fear intentional lying; for he knows from himself, peace and blessings be upon him, that he did not lie; but he feared at first that an evil occurrence might have happened to him, which is the second station. So Khadijah mentioned what negates this, which is what he was naturally disposed upon of noble morals, and beautiful characteristics and deeds, which is Truthfulness necessitating Justice and Beneficence to creation. Whoever combines in himself Truthfulness, Justice, and Beneficence is not among those whom Allah disgraces. Joining ties of kinship, hosting the guest, bearing the burden of the weak, giving the destitute, and helping in the vicissitudes of truth are among the greatest types of Righteousness and Beneficence. It is known from Allah's Sunnah (Way) that whoever Allah created with praiseworthy morals and purified from blameworthy morals, He does not disgrace him" (3).

Second Requirement: Miracles and Karamat
The Maturidis affirm the karamat (miraculous gifts) of the Awliya (saints), just as they affirm the miracles of the Prophets. They believe that there is no difference between them except the challenge (Tahaddi), which is the claim of messengership. Thus, a miracle is a supernatural event accompanied by a challenge, with the absence of opposition. A karamah, according to them, is a supernatural event not accompanied by a challenge. They see no contradiction or confusion between affirming miracles and affirming karamat; rather, the karamah of a saint is part of the miracle of the Prophet and evidence of his truthfulness, because the karamah of the follower is the karamah of the followed, and a saint is not a saint until he believes in the Prophet and follows him.
Abu al-Mu'in al-Nasafi explained the definition of a miracle, saying: "A miracle alone, according to the method of the theologians: is the appearance of a matter contrary to habit in the abode of obligation (Dar al-Taklif) to demonstrate the truthfulness of the claimant of prophethood, with the inability of those challenged to oppose it with the like. It was restricted to the abode of obligation because what appears contrary to habit in the abode of the Hereafter is not a miracle. We said 'to demonstrate the truthfulness of the claimant of prophethood' to exclude what appears for a claimant of divinity, as the appearance of that at his hand is possible according to us. It also contains a caution regarding what appears at the hand of a saint, as the appearance of that as a karamah for the saint is possible according to us. We said 'to demonstrate his truthfulness' because if that appeared to demonstrate his falsehood, it would not be a miracle for him nor evidence of his truthfulness, but rather evidence of his falsehood in his claim. We said 'with the inability of those challenged to oppose it with the like' because if the supernatural event appeared at his hand and then the like appeared at the hand of the challenger, what appeared at his hand would lose its significance upon opposition, since the like appeared at the hands of one who denies him, which would be evidence of the truthfulness of the one who denies him, so the two evidences would contradict each other and fall." (1).
Al-Nasiri said: "The difference between a Prophet and a saint is apparent, because the Prophet claims the miracle and karamah and challenges creation with it, saying: 'The sign of my message and my confirmation is such and such.' The saint does not claim the karamah; rather, it appears at his hand without challenge or claim. Whenever he claims it, he falls from the rank of sainthood and becomes a dissolute person (Fasiq). This was mentioned by the scholars of Usul, including Sayf al-Haqq Abu al-Mu'in...." (2).
It appears from the Maturidi definition of a miracle that prophethood is proven to them by three conditions: breaking the habit (supernatural), the challenge, and the lack of opposition. These conditions alone for a miracle are not disciplined due to the following:

- There is no suspension of judgment in the Book and Sunnah based on this description; indeed, there is no mention of breaking the habit, but rather therein are signs (Ayat) and proofs (Barahin) (1).
- The description of a sign as being contrary to habit is not disciplined, for prophethood itself is habitual for prophets, while it is contrary to habit for others. Soothsaying and magic are habitual matters for magicians and soothsayers, contrary to habit for others, just as medical experts know things habitual for their likes but contrary to habit for others. Thus, a miracle being a matter contrary to habit is not a disciplined matter (2).
So the Maturidi definition of a miracle by this definition is not upright and not disciplined. Furthermore, it is not mentioned in the Book or the Sunnah to name what Allah supports His prophets and messengers with as a 'miracle' (Mu'jizah), but rather it is mentioned to name them 'signs' (Ayat). On the authority of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (There is no prophet among the prophets but was given of signs what on the like of it humans believed. And indeed, what I was given was a revelation that Allah revealed to me, so I hope to be the most followed of them on the Day of Resurrection) (3).
A sign can be defined as: What Allah supports His prophets and messengers with of matters contrary to cosmic laws, which creation has no ability to bring the like of; thus being evidence of their truthfulness and Allah's support for them.
As for the karamat of the saints, they are, as they said, from the signs of the prophets; but not everything that was of the signs of the prophets is a karamah for the righteous. The Maturidis equated this and that, saying the difference is the claim of prophethood and the challenge, and this is wrong. For the signs of the prophets that indicated their prophethood are higher than what they share with their followers. The splitting of the moon, bringing the Quran, the staff turning into a snake, and the emergence of the she-camel from a rock had no like for the saints. The major signs are specific to the prophets and messengers. As for the minor signs, they may be for the righteous, such as increasing food - for example - this has been found for some righteous people, but it was not found for anyone as it was found for the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he fed an army from a small amount. Thus, participation may be in the genus of the sign, but not with the same greatness and abundance (4).

text: Section Two: Belief in the Last Day. The Maturidiyyah refer to matters related to the Last Day as 'Sam'iyyat' (things known only by textual revelation), based on their view that such matters cannot be known except through transmitted texts. That is, their only source for information concerning the Last Day is revelation. Therefore, we find that they agree with Ahl al-Sunnah wa-l-Jama'ah in this topic: they affirm the bliss of the grave, its punishment, the signs of the Hour, the resurrection, the rising, the scale, the bridge, and the Basin. However, their belief that the Last Day and everything related to it can only be known through revelation is incorrect. Rather, reason itself also indicates the Last Day, just as revelation does. In fact, revelation points to the rational indication of this, as in His saying: {Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth, and the alternation of night and day, are signs for people of understanding (190) those who remember Allah standing, sitting, and lying on their sides, and reflect on the creation of the heavens and the earth: 'Our Lord, You have not created this in vain. Glory be to You! So protect us from the punishment of the Fire.' (191) 'Our Lord, indeed whoever You admit to the Fire, You have surely disgraced him, and the wrongdoers will have no helpers.'} [l 'Imrn: 190192]. Since the vision of Allah, Exalted is He, is one of the matters pertaining to the Last Day, the Maturidiyyah affirmed it because revelation indicates it and because they consider it rationally possible. But they restricted this by negating direction and facing, because they deny the exaltedness of Allah's Essence. Therefore, they felt compelled to combine between negating exaltedness and affirming the vision. Abu Mansur al-Maturidi said: "Our position regarding the vision of the Lord, Mighty and Majestic, is that it is necessary and true, without encompassing and without modality. As for the evidence for the vision: His saying, {Eyes do not encompass Him, but He encompasses the eyes} [al-An'am: 103]. If He could not be seen, then negating encompassing would have no purpose. The second: Musa   said, {My Lord, show Yourself to me that I may look at You} [al-A'raf: 143]. If vision were impossible, then such a request would have been ignorance of his Lord. Also, His saying: {Faces on that Day will be radiant (22) looking at their Lord} [al-Qiyamah: 22]."

Topic Three: Belief in Destiny and Decree (Al-Qada' wa Al-Qadar)
Belief in Destiny and Decree is a pillar of the pillars of Faith, and Faith is not valid without it. It consists of four levels:
1 - Allah's pre-eternal knowledge of everything, and that He knew the actions of the servants before they did them.
2 - The writing of that in the Preserved Tablet (Al-Lawh Al-Mahfuz).
3 - Allah's general Will and His all-encompassing Power.
4 - Allah's bringing into existence of all creatures, and that He is the Creator and everything else is created.
This is the saying of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah, indicated by the Book, the Sunnah, and the consensus of the Companions and those who followed them in goodness (1).
Allah Almighty said: {Indeed, all things We created with predestination} [Al-Qamar: 49]. And He Almighty said: {He created each thing and determined it with [precise] determination} [Al-Furqan: 1 - 2], "Meaning everything other than Him is created and nurtured, and He is the Creator of everything, its Lord, its King, and its God. Everything is under His subjugation, management, control, and determination" (2).
And He Almighty said: {And the command of Allah is a decree determined} [Al-Ahzab: 38], "Meaning His command which He decrees is inevitable and will occur, there is no way to avoid or divert it; whatever He wills happens, and whatever He does not will does not happen" (3).
And He Almighty said: {No disaster strikes except by permission of Allah. And whoever believes in Allah - He will guide his heart. And Allah is Knowing of all things} [At-Taghabun: 11], "This is general for all calamities, in self, wealth, children, loved ones, and the like. So all that befalls the servants is by the Decree and Destiny of Allah; His knowledge has preceded it, His Pen has run with it, His Will has executed it, and His Wisdom has required it" (4).

First Requirement: The Levels of Qada' (Decree) and Qadar (Destiny) according to the Maturidiyyah:
The Maturidiyyah affirm these levels: Knowledge, Writing, General Will, and Creation. The deviation that occurred from them regarding Destiny and Decree is only related to the actions of servants. Their discussion of these four levels is not as clear as it is in the speech of Ahl al-Sunnah; for when they define Qada' and Qadar, they stipulate Knowledge and Creation, but as for Will, they mention it in their discussion of the issue of Volition (Irada), and as for Writing, they rarely mention it.
Al-Maturidi said: "Qada' in its reality is judging a thing and deciding upon what befits it and is most rightful to be decided upon. Thus, it refers back to the creation of things because it is the realization of their existence as they are, and upon the premise that everything should be as it was created; since the One who created creation is the Wise, the Knowing, and Wisdom is hitting the mark for everything and placing it in its place. Allah Almighty said: {And He completed them as seven heavens} [Fussilat: 12]. Based on that, it is permissible to describe the actions of creation as having been Decreed (Qada) by Him, meaning He created them and judged." Then he said: "As for Qadar (Destiny), it is of two aspects: One of them: The limit upon which a thing emerges, which is making everything as it is regarding good or evil, beauty or ugliness. And upon the likes of this is His saying: {Indeed, all things We created with predestination} [Al-Qamar: 49]. The second: Explaining what everything will be upon regarding time, place, truth, falsehood, and what pertains to it of reward and punishment" (1).
He also said: "Praise be to Allah who originated creation by His Power and directed them by His Wisdom based on preceding Knowledge and Will, initiating things however He willed {He is not questioned about what He does, but they will be questioned} [Al-Anbiya: 23]" (2).
Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi said, clarifying the affirmation of Writing: "... And Allah Almighty wrote in the Preserved Tablet all that will be and all that servants will do before creating them" (3).

Second Requirement: Actions of Servants
The discussion on this issue is from two aspects:
Aspect One: Creation of Servants' Actions.
The Maturidiyyah said: The actions of servants are created by Allah, and Allah Almighty created all of them, whether good or evil. They used many textual and rational evidences for this.
Al-Maturidi said: "Then the proof according to us from the way of the Quran for the necessity of saying the creation of actions is His saying: {And conceal your speech or publicize it; indeed, He is Knowing of that within the breasts. Does He who created not know, while He is the Subtle, the Acquainted?} [Al-Mulk: 13-14]. If He, Majestic is His praise, were not the Creator of what is publicized and concealed, He would not use it as argument for His knowledge. Also, that Allah Almighty said: {It is He who enables you to travel on land and sea} [Yunus: 22], and He said in another place {And We determined for them the journey. Travel therein by nights and days in safety} [Saba: 18]. He informed that the determining of the journey and the enabling of travel is His action and by Him the journey occurred" (1).
Aspect Two: The Relationship of Servants to their Actions.
The saying of the Maturidiyyah that Allah Almighty is the Creator of servants' actions, their good and their evil, is the true saying indicated by Revelation and Reason, and it is the saying of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah and the Predecessors of the Nation. But regarding the relationship of servants to their actions, the Maturidiyyah attempted to mediate between the saying of the Mu'tazila and the saying of the Jabriyyah. So they said: The actions of servants are created by Allah Almighty and are an acquisition (Kasb) by the servants.
Al-Maturidi said: "The reality of that action is that it belongs to the servants by way of acquisition and to Allah by way of creation" (2).
Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi said: "According to us, the action of the servant is Allah Almighty's creation and His effect, and Allah Almighty is the One who handles its origination and bringing it from non-existence to existence, and the servant acquired it and practiced it" (3).

Their expressions differed in explaining the meaning of Kasb (Acquisition) (1), and the summary of their speech is that the Influencer in the origin of the action is the Power of Allah Almighty, and the influencer in the description of the action is the power of the servant, and this influence of the servant is Kasb according to them.
Al-Bayadi said: "The origin of the action is by Allah's Power, and the description of it as being obedience or disobedience is by the servant's power, and this is the school of the majority of Maturidiyyah" (2).
They mean by this that Allah Almighty does not create the servant's action unless the servant wills it and chooses it, and they have stated this explicitly.
Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi said: "And what He invents - meaning Allah Almighty - in him - meaning in the servant - is by the servant's choice of that, and he has power over it. So the effect of his power relating to it is its being an action of his. So Allah Almighty is the inventor of the servant's action by his [the servant's] choice; were it not for the servant's choice and his intent to acquire it, Allah Almighty would not have created it as an action for him" (3).
The reality of this Maturidi saying is that servants have an uncreated will which is the starting point of the action. So servants, according to their school, dispose of the starting points of their actions with complete independence as they wish, and Allah Almighty's creation of their actions is merely a consequence of their uncreated will.
There is no doubt that this saying of the Maturidiyyah is false because Allah Almighty is the Creator of everything. "And God forbid, and Allah is Greater, More Glorious, and More Mighty than there being in His servant anything not created by Him nor entering under His Power and Will. He did not estimate Allah with His true estimation who claimed that, nor did he know Him with true knowledge, nor magnify Him with true magnification. Rather the servant: his body, spirit, attributes, actions, motives, and every atom in him is created by Allah with a creation by which He disposes in His servant... So he is a created servant from every angle and every consideration. His need for his Creator and Maker is from the necessities of his essence. His heart is in the hand of his Creator and between two fingers of His fingers; He turns it how He wills, making him willing what He wills to occur from him, hating what He does not will to occur. So whatever He wills happens, and whatever He does not will does not happen..." (4).

This does not mean that the servant is forced with no choice; rather, Allah Almighty created him with a "nature and attribute by which he is enabled to originate his will and actions. That nature is by Allah's Will, Power, and Formation. He is the One who created him and formed him as such, and he did not make himself as such. Rather, his Creator and Maker made him an originator of his will and actions. By that, He commanded him and forbade him, established the argument against him, and exposed him to reward and punishment. So He commanded him with what he is enabled to originate, and forbade him from what he is enabled to leave. He arranged his reward and punishment on these actions and omissions which He enabled him to do and empowered him over, and linked them to him. He created His creation with an innate nature to praise and blame him for them - the believer among them and the disbeliever, the one acknowledging the laws among them and the denier. So he was willing and wishing by Allah's Will for him; were it not for Allah's Will for him to be wishing, he would have been too incapable and weak to make himself wishing. So the Lord, Glory be to Him, gave him will, power, and volition, and taught him what benefits him and what harms him, and commanded him to run his will, volition, and power in the path by which he reaches the ultimate end of his rectification..." (1).
Allah Almighty said: {To whoever wills among you to take a right course (28) And you do not will except that Allah wills - Lord of the worlds} [At-Takwir: 28-29].
So the actions of servants are truly their actions and are done by the Lord Almighty, since the act is other than the object of the act. So the servant did his action truly "and Allah is his Creator and the Creator of what he acted with of power and will and the Creator of his agency. The secret of the issue is that the servant is an agent who is acted upon... so his Lord is the One who made him an agent by His Power and Will, empowered him over the action, and originated for him the will by which he acts" (2).

Third Requirement: Capability (Qudrah) and Ability (Istita'ah):
Istita'ah, Taqah, Qudrah, and Wus' are words with close meanings, and their opposite is 'Ajz (Incapacity). Theologians defined it as: "An existential attribute with which action is possible instead of omission, and omission instead of action" (1).
The issue of Istita'ah or Qudrah is among the issues where disagreement occurred among Islamic sects following the disagreement occurring in Destiny (Qadar). Those who said by Compulsion (Jabr) - who are the Jahmiyyah and those who agreed with them - said by negating Istita'ah neither with the action nor before it, because the servant according to them has no choice (2).
Those who said by negating Destiny and that the servant creates his action - who are the Mu'tazila and those who agreed with them - affirmed Istita'ah before the action and negated it being with it (3).
Those who said by Acquisition (Kasb) - who are the Ash'aris and those who agreed with them - said that Istita'ah is with the action, not before it (4).
As for the majority of Maturidiyyah, they took a middle path in the issue. They said by affirming Istita'ah before the action and with it. They said that Istita'ah falls into two types:
The First: Safety of causes and instruments, and this precedes the action.
The Second: The Istita'ah by which the action is prepared/enabled, and this is with the action.
Al-Maturidi said: "The principle according to us regarding what is named Power (Qudrah) is that it is of two types: One of them: Safety of causes and health of instruments, and this precedes actions. The Second: A meaning whose boundary cannot be clarified by anything referred to, except that it is only for the action; it is not permissible for it to exist in any state unless the action occurs by it when it occurs with it" (5).

Then Istita'ah according to us is two parts: One of them: Safety of causes and instruments and health of limbs and organs. This is what is meant by His saying Almighty: {And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House - for whoever is able to find thereto a way} [Al Imran: 97], and His saying Almighty: {And he who is unable - then the feeding of sixty poor persons} [Al-Mujadila: 4], and His saying Almighty informing about the hypocrites: {If we were able, we would have gone forth with you. The Second: The Istita'ah which is the reality of Power by which the action is prepared. This is what is meant by His saying Almighty: {They were not to have any protectors besides Allah; the punishment will be multiplied for them. They were not able to hear, nor did they see} [Hud: 20]. Do you not see that Allah Almighty blamed them for that? Blame only attaches to them for the absence of the reality of Power while safety of causes and health of instruments exists, not for the absence of safety of causes and health of instruments; because the negation of that Istita'ah is not by his wasting it, rather he is forced in that, so blame would not attach to them for refraining from the action upon its negation. Likewise, it is what is meant by the saying of the companion of Musa, peace be upon them: {He said, 'Indeed, with me you will never be able to have patience.'} [Al-Kahf: 67], and His saying: {He said, 'Did I not tell you that with me you would never be able to have patience?'} [Al-Kahf: 75]. For if the intended meaning were safety of causes and instruments, he would not have reproached him for abandoning patience. The second Istita'ah is an accident ('Arad) that occurs according to us concurrent with the action..." (1).
The saying of the majority of Maturidiyyah regarding Istita'ah is the saying of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah (2), and it is the true saying indicated by evidences.

Al-Tahawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "And the Istita'ah by which the action becomes mandatory, regarding Tawfiq (divine success) which is not permissible to describe the created being with, is with the action. As for the Istita'ah from the aspect of health, capacity, enablement, and safety of instruments, it is before the action, and the Address (Khitab) relates to it."
Ibn Abi Al-Izz, may Allah have mercy on him, explaining Al-Tahawi's words said: "And what the generality of Ahl al-Sunnah said is that the servant has a power which is the basis of command and prohibition, and this may be before it [the action] and does not have to be with it. And the power by which the action occurs must be with the action; it is not permissible for the action to exist with a non-existent power. As for the power from the aspect of health, capacity, enablement, and safety of instruments, it may precede actions. This is the power mentioned in His saying Almighty: {And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House - for whoever is able to find thereto a way. But whoever disbelieves - then indeed, Allah is free from need of the worlds} [Al Imran: 97], and likewise His saying Almighty: {So fear Allah as much as you are able} [At-Taghabun: 16], and likewise His saying Almighty: {And he who is unable - then the feeding of sixty poor persons} [Al-Mujadila: 4]. The intended meaning is the capability of causes and instruments... As for the proof of affirming the Istita'ah which is the reality of Power, they mentioned regarding it His saying Almighty: {They were not able to hear, nor did they see} [Hud: 20]; the intended meaning is negating the reality of Power, not negating causes and instruments..." (1).

Fourth Requirement: Burdening Beyond Capacity (Taklif ma la yutaq):
The issue of burdening beyond capacity is also among the issues where disagreement occurred among Muslim sects, following the disagreement occurring in Istita'ah and Rational Goodness and Badness.
The Jahmiyyah said it is permissible to burden beyond capacity absolutely (1).
The Mu'tazila said it is not permissible to burden beyond capacity; because it is rationally bad (Qabih), and Allah Almighty is transcendent above doing the bad, so it is not permissible for it to issue from Him (2).
The Ash'aris said it is permissible to burden beyond capacity rationally, even if it did not occur in the Sharia. They permitted it rationally based on their negation of rational Goodness and Badness (3).
As for the Maturidiyyah, they agreed with the Mu'tazila in this issue. They said it is not permissible to burden beyond capacity; because it is corrupt rationally, and due to the absence of the Power which is the requirement of obligation (Taklif).
Al-Maturidi said: "The principle is that burdening one who is prevented from capacity is corrupt in reason" (4).
Ibn Al-Humam said: "I do not know anyone of them (i.e., the Maturidiyyah) who permitted burdening beyond capacity" (5).
The correct view in the issue is detailing, so it is said: "Burdening beyond capacity divides into two types:
One of them: What cannot be borne due to inability to do it, like burdening the chronically ill to walk, and burdening the human to fly and the like. This does not occur in the Sharia according to the majority of Ahl al-Sunnah who affirm Destiny.
The Second: What cannot be borne due to being occupied with its opposite, like the disbeliever being occupied with disbelief; for it is what prevented him from faith, and like the sitter in the state of his sitting; for his occupation with sitting prevents him from being standing. The decisive will for one of two opposites negates the will for the other opposite, and charging the disbeliever with faith is of this category.
The likes of this is not bad rationally according to any of the rationals; rather, rationals agree on commanding the human and forbidding him regarding what he cannot do at the moment of command and prohibition due to his engagement with its opposite, if it is possible to leave the opposite and do the commanded opposite. This does not enter into 'what cannot be borne'; for it is not said to the capable one commanded with Hajj if he does not perform Hajj that he was burdened with what he cannot bear, nor is it said to the one commanded with purification and prayer if he leaves that out of laziness that he was burdened with what he cannot bear" (6).

Chapter Four: Issues of Faith (Iman)
Containing five topics:
Topic One: Meaning of Faith.
Topic Two: Increase and decrease of Faith.
Topic Three: Exception (Istithna) in Faith.
Topic Four: Relationship between Faith and Islam.

Topic One: Meaning and Reality of Faith
The Maturidiyyah went to say that Faith is Assent (Tasdiq) by the heart only, and some of them went to say it is Assent by the heart and Confession (Iqrar) by the tongue (1).
Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi said: "Faith in language is an expression for Assent (Tasdiq). So everyone who believes another in what he informs is called in language a believer in him and a believer for him. Allah Almighty said: {But you would not be a believer for us} [Yusuf: 17] meaning a ratifier (Musaddiq) for us. Then the linguistic [meaning] which is Assent by the heart is the reality of Faith obligatory upon the servant as a right to Allah Almighty, which is that he believes the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, in what he brought from Allah Almighty. So whoever brings this Assent is a believer between him and Allah Almighty (2).
This saying contradicts the saying of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah. For the root 'Amina' means in language: trusted and felt secure, and Amanah (Trust) is Wuthuq (Reliability) (3). It is said: "I did not feel secure (Amintu) that I would find his companion, meaning I did not trust" (4). Al-Raghib Al-Asfahani, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "The origin of Amn is tranquility of the soul and removal of fear" (5). Iman is the verbal noun of Amana Yu'minu Imanan so he is Mu'min (6). The origin of Amana is A'mana with two Hamzas, the second was softened (7). It is from Amn (Safety) opposite of Fear (8).
Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, said in his definition of Faith: "... For its derivation is from Amn which is acknowledgment (Iqrar) and tranquility (Tuma'ninah), and that is only achieved if Assent (Tasdiq) and Compliance (Inqiyad) settle in the heart" (9). This acknowledgment includes the speech of the heart which is Assent, and the action of the heart which is Compliance.

As for the meaning of Faith: It is Assent along with Compliance. It sometimes becomes transitive with 'Ba' and sometimes with 'Lam'. From the first - transitive with 'Ba' - it is said: Amana bihi qawmun (A people believed in him) (1) and Kadhdhaba bihi qawmun (A people denied him). From it is His saying Almighty: {Those who believe in the Unseen} [Al-Baqarah: 3]. Meaning they believe the reports of Allah regarding Paradise and Hell (2).
From the second - transitive with 'Lam' - is His saying Almighty informing about the Jews that they said: {And do not believe except for one who follows your religion} [Al Imran: 73], meaning do not acknowledge nor believe (3). And from it is His saying Almighty: {But you would not be a believer for us} [Yusuf: 17], meaning a ratifier for us (4). The difference between them is that the transitive with 'Ba' is believing the report itself, and the transitive with 'Lam' is believing the reporter (5).
So Faith is: Confession by tongue, Belief by heart, and Action by limbs. It increases with obedience to the Most Merciful, and decreases with obedience to Satan (6).
Imam Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "The consensus of the Companions and the Followers after them whom we met was: That Faith is: Speech, Action, and Intention; none of the three suffices without the other" (7).
Muhammad bin Hussein Al-Ajurri, may Allah have mercy on him, said in the chapter "The saying that Faith is Assent by the heart, Confession by the tongue, and Action by the limbs; one is not a believer unless these three qualities gather in him", he said: "Know, may Allah have mercy on us and you, that what Muslim scholars are upon is that Faith is obligatory on all creation, and it is Assent by the heart, Confession by the tongue, and Action by the limbs. Then know that knowledge by the heart and Assent do not suffice unless there is with it Faith by the tongue verbally, and knowledge of the heart and pronunciation of the tongue do not suffice until there is action by the limbs. If these three qualities are complete in him, he is a believer. The Book, the Sunnah, and the saying of Muslim scholars indicate that..." (8).

The evidences for the inclusion of these matters in the name of Faith are many, including:
His saying Almighty regarding the heart's assent and certainty: {And the one who has brought the truth and [they who] believed in it - those are the righteous. (33) They will have whatever they desire with their Lord. That is the reward of the doers of good (34)} [Az-Zumar: 33 - 34]. And He Almighty said: {And thus did We show Abraham the realm of the heavens and the earth that he would be among the certain [in faith] (75)}.
In the Hadith of Intercession: (He exits the Fire who said: There is no god but Allah, and in his heart is good equal to the weight of a barley grain) (1).
And His saying Almighty regarding mentioning some actions of the hearts like sincerity, love, compliance, turning to Allah Mighty and Majestic, relying on Him, and the requirements and consequents of that. Allah Almighty said: {And do not send away those who call upon their Lord morning and afternoon, seeking His countenance} [Al-An'am: 52]. And He said: {And not [giving] for anyone who has with Him a favor to be rewarded (19) But only seeking the countenance of his Lord, Most High (20)} [Al-Layl: 19 - 20], and other texts indicating the obligation of reliance, fear, hope, dread, submission, turning in repentance, and other actions of the hearts.
Among them is His saying Almighty regarding pronouncing the Two Testimonies: testifying that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, and acknowledging their implications. Allah Almighty said: {Say, "We have believed in Allah and what has been revealed to us and what has been revealed to Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac and Jacob and the Descendants and what was given to Moses and Jesus and what was given to the prophets from their Lord. We make no distinction between any of them, and we are Muslims [in submission] to Him."} [Al-Baqarah: 136]. And He Almighty said: {And when it is recited to them, they say, "We have believed in it; indeed, it is the truth from our Lord"} [Al-Qasas: 53]. And he said, peace and blessings be upon him: (I have been commanded to fight the people until they testify that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah...) (2).
Among them is His saying Almighty regarding actions performed by the tongue like reciting the Quran and all remembrances like Tasbih, Tahmid, Takbir, Dua, Istighfar, etc.: {Indeed, those who recite the Book of Allah and establish prayer and spend [in His cause] out of what We have provided them, secretly and publicly, [can] expect a transaction that will never perish (29)} [Fatir: 29]. And He said: {And recite, [O Muhammad], what has been revealed to you of the Book of your Lord. There is no changer of His words} [Al-Kahf: 27]. And He said: {O you who have believed, remember Allah with much remembrance (41) And exalt Him morning and afternoon (42)} [Al-Ahzab: 41 - 42].

Topic Two: Increase and Decrease of Faith
This issue is built upon the previous one; since the Maturidiyyah said that Faith is Assent (Tasdiq) and that actions are not included in the name of Faith, they said: Faith does not increase or decrease. They based this on the premise that Assent does not accept increase and decrease.
Al-Hakim Al-Samarqandi said: "And it should be known that Faith does not increase or decrease; because whoever sees increase and decrease in Faith is an innovator. Increase and decrease are only in actions, not in Faith. And no one from the scholars and righteous said that Faith increases and decreases" (1).
Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi said: "If it is proven that Faith is Assent, and it does not increase in itself, it indicates that Faith does not increase or decrease. So there is no increase to it by the addition of acts of obedience to it, nor decrease to it by committing sins, since Assent in both states is as it was before them" (2).
This saying contradicts the saying of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah, which is that Faith increases with obedience and decreases with disobedience (3). The evidences for the increase and decrease of Faith from the Book, the Sunnah, and the traditions of the Salaf are very many:
Among them: His saying Almighty {And when His verses are recited to them, it increases them in faith} [Al-Anfal: 2]. And He Almighty said: {And Allah increases those who were guided, in guidance} [Maryam: 76]. And He Almighty said: {And that those who believe may increase in faith} [Al-Muddaththir: 31]. And He Almighty said: {It is He who sent down tranquility into the hearts of the believers that they would increase in faith along with their [present] faith} [Al-Fath: 4].
The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, described women with deficiency in reason and religion, saying: (... I have not seen any lacking in reason and religion more overwhelming to a man of intellect than you) (4).
In the Hadith of Intercession: (Go and bring out whoever has in his heart the lowest, lowest, lowest weight of a mustard seed of faith, bring him out of the Fire) (5).
The speech of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, and those after them regarding this meaning is also plentiful:
Abu Darda said: "It is from the Fiqh (understanding) of the servant to tend to his faith and what decreased of it, and it is from the Fiqh of the servant to know whether he increases or decreases?" (6).
Ibn Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, used to say in his supplication: "O Allah, increase us in faith, certainty, and understanding" (7).
Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Faith is speech and action, it increases with obedience, and decreases with disobedience" (8).
Al-Bukhari, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "I met more than a thousand men from the scholars in the regions, I did not see any of them differ that Faith is speech and action, and it increases and decreases" (9).

Topic Three: Exception (Istithna) in Faith
What is meant by Exception in Faith is: Suspending Faith on the Will [of Allah], which is the believer saying: I am a believer Insha'Allah (If Allah wills).
Since the Maturidiyyah said that Faith is Assent, and that it does not accept increase and decrease, they forbade Exception in Faith. They said: Exception is doubt, and whoever doubts in his assent is a disbeliever.
Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi said: "The principle according to us is decisiveness in saying Faith and naming oneself with it absolutely and abandoning Exception in it; because every meaning where the gathering of its existence is the completion of Faith according to him, if exception is made in it, that meaning is not valid. So based on that is his matter in general, like saying: I testify that there is no god but Allah, Insha'Allah, or Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, Insha'Allah, and likewise testimony of Resurrection, Angels, Messengers, and Books" (1).
Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi said: "Then since it - meaning Faith - is a name for Assent, and it is a real thing with known boundary, if it occurs with this boundary the Essence is by it a believer, like sitting, standing, blackness, whiteness, etc. Since they are meanings of known boundary, when they exist in their reality the Essence is by them sitting, standing, black, white, so is this. By knowing this, it is known that when Assent exists, Faith has existed in its reality. So the saying of one who says: I am a believer Insha'Allah; with the existence of the reality of Assent, is like the saying of one who says: I am standing Insha'Allah, and I am sitting Insha'Allah while the reality of that exists, and that is void so is this" (2).
So the Maturidiyyah forbade Exception in Faith because the concept and reality of Faith for them is Assent or Assent and Speech.

The intended meaning of Exception in Faith is suspending Faith on the Will [of Allah], which is the believer saying I am a believer Insha'Allah. The disagreement in this issue occurred following the disagreement on the reality of Faith. The summary of the sayings said regarding Exception are three opinions:
First: Prohibition of Exception
If the Exception stems from doubt in the existence of the foundation of Faith, this is forbidden, rather disbelief; because Faith is decisiveness, and doubt contradicts it. The basis of this saying: Faith is one thing the person knows of himself, so if he makes exception in it, it is proof of his doubt; therefore, they used to call those who make exception in Faith 'Doubters' (Shukkak).
Second: Obligation of Exception:
If the Exception stems from fear of self-praise and testifying for oneself of perfecting Faith in word, deed, and belief, this is obligatory; out of fear of this prohibition. Also, Faith is what a person dies upon; so a person is only a believer or disbeliever according to death, and this is a future unknown matter; so it is not permissible to be decisive about it.
Third: Detailing:
- If the Exception stems from doubt in the existence of the foundation of Faith, this is forbidden, rather disbelief; because Faith is decisiveness, and doubt contradicts it.
- If it stems from fear of self-praise and testifying for oneself of achieving Faith in word, deed, and belief, or that Faith is what a person dies upon; for a person is only a believer or disbeliever according to death, and this is a future unknown matter; so it is not permissible to be decisive about it, then this is obligatory.
- If the intent of Exception is seeking blessing by mentioning the Will or stating the cause, and that what exists in his heart of Faith is by Allah's Will, this is permissible. Suspension in this manner - I mean stating the cause - does not contradict the realization of the suspended matter. For suspension in this manner has appeared regarding realized matters; like His saying Almighty: {Certainly has Allah showed to His Messenger the vision in truth. You will surely enter al-Masjid al-Haram, if Allah wills, in safety, with your heads shaved and [hair] shortened, not fearing} [Al-Fath: 27]. Likewise, the supplication in visiting graves: (And we, if Allah wills, will follow you) (1)" (2).

Topic Four: Relationship between Faith and Islam
The Maturidiyyah went in this issue to say that Islam and Iman (Faith) are one thing, and there is no variance between them, and one does not separate from the other, and if one disappears the other disappears, and that the difference between them is in the meaning by language.
Abu Mansur Al-Maturidi said: "As for the saying according to us regarding Faith and Islam, it is one in the matter of religion in verification of intent, even if they may differ in meaning by language. Then from the aspect of verification of intent in religion, Faith is a name for the testimony of minds and traces by Assent to the Oneness of Allah Almighty, and that to Him belongs Creation and Command in creation having no partner in that. And Islam is the submission of the person himself entirely and likewise everything to Allah Almighty by servitude to Allah having no partner in it. So they resulted in intent as one. Then the principle is that it is far from reason that a person comes with all conditions of Faith then is not a Muslim, or comes with all conditions of Islam then is not a believer. It is proven that they are in reality one, and it is known that whoever is permitted to be named by one of them is permitted [to be named] by the other" (1).
People in this issue are on three opinions:
First: That Islam and Faith are names for one named thing.
Second: That Islam is the Word and Faith is the Action.
Third: Detailing, and it is the Truth; which is that the state of their conjunction is different from the state of their isolation. If they are conjoined, the intended meaning of Islam is apparent actions and Faith is hidden actions. If they are isolated, their meaning is one and one enters into the other, and the intended meaning is all apparent and hidden matters of religion.
Its meaning: That Islam and Faith if gathered in one text from Book or Sunnah, then each one has a meaning specific to it. So Islam: Apparent actions including the Two Testimonies and Prayer... And Faith: Hidden actions of beliefs like Reliance, Fear, Love, Hope, Dread... etc.

Many evidences indicated this, including:
His saying Almighty: {The Bedouins say, "We have believed." Say, "You have not [yet] believed; but say [instead], 'We have submitted,' for faith has not yet entered your hearts.} [Al-Hujurat: 14]. So they gathered in one text, and He negated Faith from them, and affirmed Islam for them; which indicated their separation, that they are Muslims but did not reach being believers.
And the famous Hadith of Gabriel, peace be upon him (1), in which Islam is mentioned: by the five pillars, and Faith: by the six fundamentals. For they gathered in one text, and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, answered for each with a meaning other than the other; which indicated their separation.
The meaning of their separation [in definition]: That one of them comes in a text without the other, then one of them has the meaning of the other, so Islam is Faith and vice versa.
There are many evidences for this in the two Revelations: Among them His saying Almighty in Surah Ali Imran: {And whoever desires other than Islam as religion - never will it be accepted from him, and he, in the Hereafter, will be among the losers} [Ali Imran: 85]. And in its beginning His saying Almighty: {Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam} [Ali Imran: 19]. So we implied that the religion in the sight of Allah is Faith, and whoever desires other than Faith as religion, it will not be accepted from him.
And from it His saying Almighty in His address to the believers in many verses: {O you who have believed}; for the address is also directed to those who submitted and Faith has not yet entered their hearts, which indicates one covering the other when alone.
Among the most explicit evidences from the Sunnah on their separation making their meaning one is the Hadith of the delegation of Abd Qays, agreed upon its authenticity from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that they came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah, between us and you is this tribe of Mudar and we cannot come to you except in the sacred months, so command us with a decisive command we can inform those behind us with, and enter Paradise by it? So he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (I command you to believe in Allah alone. Do you know what belief in Allah alone is? They said: Allah and His Messenger know best! He said: To testify that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establish prayer, give Zakat, fast Ramadan, and give one-fifth of the booty) (2). For the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, informed them in the Hadith about Faith by the pillars of Islam, which indicated that they are of one meaning, which implies that one suffices for the other when separated.

Topic Five: Ruling on the Perpetrator of a Major Sin
The Maturidiyyah went to say that the perpetrator of a major sin - who does not consider it lawful - does not exit Faith and does not enter Disbelief; rather he is a believer with complete faith due to the non-removal of Assent, and he is with his faith a Fasiq (sinner) deserving of threat due to his lack of obedience to Allah Almighty and his committing of sins and offenses.
They said if the perpetrator of a major sin dies without repentance, he is under the Will [of Allah], if He wills He punishes him, and if He wills He forgives him, and if punished he exits the Fire inevitably.
Abu Al-Mu'in Al-Nasafi said: "As for the People of Truth, they say: Whoever commits a major sin not considering it lawful, nor belittling the One who forbade it; but due to being overcome by desire or zeal, hoping Allah forgives him, and fearing He punishes him for it; this one's name is Believer, and he remains on what he was on of Faith, and his faith did not cease, nor decrease, and he does not exit Faith except from the door he entered it. His ruling is that if he dies without repentance, Allah Almighty has the Will regarding him, if He wills He pardons him by His bounty and generosity or by the blessing of what he has of Faith and good deeds or by the intercession of some righteous ones, and if He wills He punishes him according to his sin then the outcome of his affair is Paradise inevitably and he does not stay eternally in the Fire. As for the name, it is because Faith is Assent and Disbelief is Denial, and this one who committed this major sin, Assent remained with him, and as long as Assent exists Denial is non-existent due to the opposition between them. So saying his disbelief while Denial is non-existent or the cessation of Faith while Assent stands or the establishment of Hypocrisy while Assent is settled in the heart is a saying of manifest corruption. Then applying the name Fasiq is because he exited the boundary of compliance, and Fisq in language is exiting, then exiting from compliance, and it does not oppose Assent so Assent remains, and if it remains the ratifier is a believer by necessity" (1).
The truth and correct view in ruling on the perpetrator of a major sin regarding worldly rulings is to say: He is "a believer with incomplete faith, a believer by his faith, a Fasiq by his major sin, and he is not given the absolute name of Faith; for the Book and Sunnah negated the absolute name from him, and the name of Faith covers him in what Allah and His Messenger commanded; because that is an obligation on him and prohibition on him and it is binding on him as it binds others" (2).
As for their saying that the perpetrator of a major sin if he dies without repentance is under the will of Allah, if He wills He pardons him and if He wills He punishes him, then the outcome of his affair is to Paradise and he does not stay eternally in the Fire, it is the true saying in the issue and it is the school of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah and the Predecessors of this Nation.
Al-Tahawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "And the people of major sins from the nation of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, do not stay eternally in the Fire if they die while they are monotheists even if they did not repent after meeting Allah as knowers [believers]. They are in His Will and Judgment, if He wills He forgives them and pardons them by His bounty as He Mighty and Majestic mentioned in His Book {He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills} [An-Nisa: 48], and if He wills He punishes them in the Fire by His justice then brings them out of it by His mercy and the intercession of intercessors from the people of His obedience then sends them to His Paradise. That is because Allah Almighty is the Ally of the people of His knowledge, and did not make them in both abodes like the people of His denial who failed to receive His guidance and did not attain His guardianship. O Allah, Ally of Islam and its people, make us firm on Islam until we meet You with it" (3).

Preface
The observer of the Maturidi creed and the Ash'ari creed finds great convergence between them. This convergence is what created agreement and harmony between them, until each of them started applying the name Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah to both sects.
What appears - and Allah Almighty knows best the truth - is that Maturidiyyah emerged from Kullabiyyah just as Ash'ariyyah did. The evidence for this is that the most distinctive feature of Maturidiyyah is the saying of the pre-eternity of Takwin, and this was said by Kullabiyyah before the appearance of Maturidiyyah. Also, the Kullabi school was widespread in the lands of Transoxiana, which are the lands where Al-Maturidi lived and died... So based on this, Al-Maturidi must have taken from his Sheikhs from the Kullabiyyah and was influenced by them. By this, the secret of the convergence between Ash'aris and Maturidis becomes clear, and Allah Almighty knows best the truth (1).
Al-Subki - who is Ash'ari - said in Al-Tabaqat: "I examined the books of the Hanafis - meaning the Maturidis due to their following the Hanafi school - and I found all the issues in which there is disagreement between us and the Hanafis to be thirteen issues. Of them, six are semantic (related to meaning) and the rest are verbal. Those six semantic ones do not necessitate their opposing us, nor our opposing them in them to the extent of Takfir (declaring disbelief) or Tabdi' (declaring innovation). I have a poem ending in Nun (Nuniyyah) in which I gathered these issues, and added to it issues in which Ash'aris differed among themselves with confirming each other in the root of creed and their claim that they are all on the Sunnah" (2).
Also, Al-Bayadi devoted a chapter in his book "Isharat Al-Maram" to explain the controversial issues between Ash'aris and Maturidis, and mentioned that the disagreement between them occurs in fifty issues. He also presented the details of the controversial issues with their evidences in all chapters of the book. He mentioned that the disagreement between Ash'aris and Maturidis is semantic, but it is in branches where disagreement does not necessitate Tabdi'. Thus, the book is considered one of the most important references in knowing the disagreement between Ash'aris and Maturidis (3).
Zahid Al-Kawthari says: "Al-Ash'ari and Al-Maturidi are the two Imams of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah in the easts and wests of the earth. They have countless books. Most of what occurred between these two Imams of disagreement is of the type of verbal disagreement. Several books have been written on that, and Al-Bayadi summarized it well in "Isharat Al-Maram fi Ibarat Al-Imam", and Al-Zabidi quoted his text in "Sharh Al-Ihya" (4).

Topic One: Issues of Real Disagreement Between Them (1)
The most important issues where disagreement occurred between Maturidiyyah and Ash'ariyyah and the disagreement was real not verbal, and substantial not branching:
Issue One: Knowledge of Allah Almighty: The Maturidiyyah said that knowledge of Allah Almighty is obligatory by reason, and that if He Almighty did not send a messenger to people, it would be obligatory on them by their intellects to know His existence Almighty, His oneness, His description with befitting attributes, that He is the Originator of the world and its Maker, and that whoever revelation did not reach is not excused. As for the Ash'aris, they said: Knowledge of Allah Almighty is obligatory by Sharia, and no faith is obligatory nor disbelief prohibited before the arrival of Sharia. Therefore, they said: The one growing up on a mountain peak whom the Call did not reach is excused.
Issue Two: Attribute of Will: The Maturidiyyah went to say that Will does not imply Pleasure (Rida) and Love (Mahabbah). The Ash'aris went to say that Love, Pleasure, and Will are synonymous.
Issue Three: Attribute of Speech: The Maturidiyyah went to say that Allah's speech is not heard; rather what is heard is what expresses it. So Moses only heard a sound and letters created by Allah indicating His speech. The Ash'aris went to say the permissibility of hearing Allah Almighty's speech, and that what Moses, peace be upon him, heard was Allah Almighty's Psychological Speech, and that is by creating a perception in the listener.
Issue Four: Attribute of Takwin (Bringing into being): The Maturidiyyah said that Takwin is a pre-eternal attribute of Allah Almighty, and that Takwin is other than the Mukawwan (thing brought into being). The Ash'aris went to say that Takwin is not an attribute of Allah Almighty, but rather a conceptual matter occurring in the mind from attributing the Influencer to the Effect. Thus, they said that Takwin is the same as the Mukawwan and it is temporal.
Issue Five: Burdening beyond capacity: The Maturidiyyah went to say the impermissibility of burdening beyond capacity. The majority of Ash'aris went to say that burdening beyond capacity is permissible.
Issue Six: Wisdom and Causality in Allah Almighty's actions: The Maturidiyyah went to say the necessity of wisdom in Allah Almighty's actions, and that it is not permissible for them to be devoid of it absolutely. The Ash'aris went to negate wisdom and causality in Allah Almighty's actions, and said: His actions are not caused by purposes, and it is not permissible to explain His actions Almighty by any purposes or teleological causes.

Issue Seven: Goodness and Badness (Tahsin and Taqbih): The Maturidiyyah went to say that the intellect perceives the goodness and badness of things, meaning they said by Rational Goodness and Badness. As for the Ash'aris, they went to say that the goodness and badness of things is not known by reason, but is only known by Sharia.
Issue Eight: Ability (Istita'ah): The majority of Maturidiyyah went to say that Ability falls into two types: First: Safety of causes and instruments, and it precedes the action. Second: The Ability by which the action is prepared, and it is with the action. As for the Ash'aris, they went to say that Ability is only with the action, and it is not permissible for it to precede it nor follow it.
Issue Nine: Acquisition (Kasb): The Maturidiyyah and Ash'aris agreed that servants' actions are created by Allah Almighty, and are an acquisition by servants, but they differed in the meaning of Kasb. The Maturidiyyah said: The Influencer in the origin of the action is Allah Almighty's power, and the influencer in the description of the action is the servant's power, and this influence of the servant is Kasb. So the servant's power according to Maturidiyyah has an effect on the action, but no effect in origination because Allah Almighty is unique in creation, but its effect is in the intent and choice of the action. As for Kasb according to Ash'aris, it is that the voluntary actions of servants occur by Allah Almighty's power alone, and their power has no effect on them. Rather, Allah Glory be to Him made it His habit to create in the servant power and choice, so if there is no impediment He creates His decreed action in him concurrently with them. So the action is created by Allah as invention and origination, and acquired by the servant. The intended meaning of his acquiring it is: its concurrence with his power and will without there being any effect or entry from him in its existence other than being a locus for it.
Issue Ten: Faith of the Imitator: The Maturidiyyah went to say the validity of the imitator's faith. As for the Ash'aris, they went to say the invalidity of the imitator's faith, and said: One of the conditions of valid faith is knowing every issue with a definitive rational proof.
Issue Eleven: Reward and Punishment: The Maturidiyyah and Ash'aris agree on saying the impermissibility of punishing the obedient and rewarding the disobedient. However, the point of disagreement between them is in the source. The Maturidiyyah went to say that the source for that is Reason and Sharia. As for the Ash'aris, they went to say that the source for that is Sharia. It resulted from that that the Maturidiyyah forbade the permissibility of punishing the obedient and rewarding the disobedient, while the Ash'aris permitted that (1).
Issue Twelve: Infallibility of Prophets: The Maturidiyyah said by the infallibility of Prophets from major sins and shameful acts especially regarding the matter of Sharia, conveying rulings, and guiding the nation. The Maturidiyyah also go to say that Prophets are infallible from minor sins, and they obliged interpreting everything that gave an impression [otherwise] regarding them, peace be upon them, from the Book and Sunnah which deceived some of those who permitted minor sins for them. So Prophets are transcendent above minor and major sins and all disobediences. While the Ash'aris go to say that minor sins may issue from Prophets before Prophethood if they are not vile and there is no proof preventing that, whether that was intentionally or by mistake. As for after Prophethood, Prophets are infallible from intentionally doing anything that breaches their truthfulness even if it is from minor sins (2).

Topic Two: Issues of Verbal Disagreement Between Them (1)
As for the issues verbally disputed, they are:
Issue One: Happiness and Misery: The Maturidiyyah see that Happiness and Misery are in the current state, and not pre-eternal. Thus, the Happy one for them is the believer in the current state, and if he dies on disbelief he has turned miserable after being happy. And the Miserable one is the disbeliever in the current state, and if he dies on faith he has turned happy. As for the Ash'aris: The concept of Happiness for them is dying on Faith, and that is - considering the attachment of Allah Almighty's knowledge - pre-eternally so. Likewise, Misery for them is dying on Disbelief. Thus, the Happy one for them is happy in pre-eternity and the Miserable one is miserable in pre-eternity, and the Happy does not change to miserable nor the Miserable to happy.
Issue Two: Ruling on the continuation of Prophethood after the death of Messengers: According to the Maturidiyyah, Messengers and Prophets remain so even after their death, i.e., in their capacity as Prophets and Messengers. As for the Ash'aris, they see that Prophets and Messengers after their death are in the ruling (Hukm) of the Message, and the ruling of a thing stands in place of its origin. Thus, it becomes clear that both parties agree on the principle of the issue which is that the Message remains until now, but the disagreement is whether the Message remains essentially or in the ruling of the Message.
Issue Three: Will (Irada), and does it imply Pleasure and Love or not? The Maturidiyyah affirm Allah Almighty's comprehensive Will for servants' actions, because servants' actions are of His creation Almighty. Saying the absence of Allah's comprehensive Will means: Allah's lack of power over their actions, for saying Absolute Power, Absolute Will, and Absolute Knowledge is necessary for the perfection of the attributes of Divinity. However, the Maturidiyyah say: There is no Love in the attribute of Will, and this Will does not imply Pleasure and Love. As for the Ash'aris, they see that Will is Pleasure and Love, since Love is Will, and Pleasure likewise means Will, and Will implies Pleasure and Love. Thus, Will, Love, Volition (Mashi'ah), Pleasure, and Choice are all one meaning.
Issue Four: Exception in Faith: The Maturidiyyah define Faith as Assent by the heart and Confession by the tongue. The Ash'aris define it as Assent in Allah Almighty. The Maturidiyyah went to forbid the entry of Exception in Faith, so the believer for them is a believer truly and not a believer by Will [saying Insha'Allah], because the Maturidiyyah see that Exception is doubt in the believer's faith and its conditions which do not accept doubt. While the Ash'aris go to the permissibility of Exception in Faith, so the believer can say: I am a believer Insha'Allah. Thus, it appears that the locus of disagreement is that the Maturidiyyah do not permit Exception in Faith, while the Ash'aris permit that.

Issue Five: Faith of the Imitator: The Maturidiyyah go to say the validity of the imitator's faith, because with this faith there is Assent, and Assent is the origin of Faith. According to them also, it is valid to suffice with imitation in religious beliefs; however, the imitator is considered sinful for leaving observation (Nazar) if he is capable of that. As for the Ash'aris, they say that imitation is not sufficient in religious beliefs, but there must be decisive belief originating from proof; because Faith is from the fundamental issues, and these are few and can be encompassed, and general knowledge suffices in them, and ability to express that is not a condition for them. They go to say that the imitator is sinful for leaving observation and deduction, but he is not a polytheist or disbeliever.
Issue Six: Acquisition (Kasb): The Maturidiyyah affirm for the servant a power and will that has an effect on the action, but has no effect on origination and invention. Its effect focuses on describing the action as obedience or disobedience. This power is represented in the intent and choice of the action. Allah Glory be to Him and Most High creates for the servant the power to act, and the result of the action is upon him. Thus, the Maturidiyyah affirm that the servant has choice in his actions, and these actions are what praise and blame in the world are based on, as well as reward and punishment in the Hereafter. As for the Ash'aris, they go to say that the servants' power by which the action occurred is not created [by the servant? context implies uncreated influence or no influence, checking text: standard Ashari view is power is created but ineffective], and that their affair is in their hands [text seems confused or attributing Mu'tazili view? Standard Ashari is created power with no effect. Re-reading Arabic: "power... is not created" seems to contradict Ashari tenets. However, sticking to translation]. And on it is the pivot of their obligation. Will according to Ash'aris is partial will, as for universal will according to them, it is created by Allah Almighty. [Note: The Arabic text description of Ashari view here is theological and complex, translation is literal].
Issue Seven: Is the disbeliever blessed (recipient of Ni'mah) or not? The Maturidiyyah see that the disbeliever is blessed, but this blessing occurred in the world only. The Ash'aris see that the disbeliever is not blessed neither in religion nor in the world nor in the Hereafter (1).

Conclusion
Summary of Doctrinal Issues in which the Maturidiyyah opposed the Salaf
After this brief study; the most important issues in which the Maturidiyyah opposed the creed of the Salaf are as follows:
1 - The disagreement of the Maturidiyyah in the concept of Tawhid, as for them it means that Allah is One in His Essence having no divider or part, One in His Attributes having no like, and One in His Actions having no partner.
2 - The Maturidiyyah relied in proving the existence of Allah Almighty on the proof of the temporal origination of accidents and bodies.
3 - The Maturidiyyah infer the Oneness of Allah Almighty by His saying Mighty and Majestic: {Had there been within the heavens and earth gods besides Allah, they both would have been ruined. So exalted is Allah, Lord of the Throne, above what they describe} [Al-Anbiya: 22], which is called the Proof of Mutual Prevention. The Salaf faulted them in this concept, while acknowledging that the Proof of Mutual Prevention is correct in its indication of the impossibility of the world emanating from two gods, but this is not what is intended by the noble verse.
4 - The Maturidiyyah affirm all Beautiful Names due to the indication of Hearing (Revelation) for them, but they exceeded bounds in affirmation and the indication of names due to not differentiating between what came in the chapter of Naming and what came in the chapter of Informing about Allah. The indication of the Name for them is the Essence and this is specific to the name "Allah" only. As for other than it, its indication is taken by them from the attributes they affirmed, so they did not stop at what was established by Hearing only.
5 - The Maturidis stopped in the chapter of Attributes at affirming some attributes but not others. They affirmed of attributes: Power, Knowledge, Life, Will, Hearing, Sight, Speech, Takwin, due to the indication of reason for them according to them.
6 - The Maturidiyyah negated all Informative Attributes established by the Book and Sunnah, because in affirming them - according to their claim - is opposition to reason which sees in affirming them what calls to describing Allah Almighty with Likening and Anthropomorphism.
7 - The Maturidiyyah negated the Voluntary Attributes of Allah Almighty which are the active attributes necessitated for Allah Almighty, because they also lead to Likening and Anthropomorphism.

8 - The Maturidiyyah went to say that the Speech of Allah Almighty is one pre-eternal meaning, having no connection to Allah Almighty's Will and Power, and that it is not with letter and voice, but rather it is Psychological Speech not heard, but what is heard of it is only an expression of it.
9 - The Maturidiyyah restricted the proof of the truthfulness of Prophets to the appearance of miracles at their hands, because they yield certain knowledge alone according to their claim.
10 - The Maturidiyyah see that all issues related to the Last Day are not known except by Hearing. The Salaf oppose them in this, and say: Those issues were known by Hearing and indicated by Reason as well.
11 - The Maturidis affirmed the Vision of Allah Almighty, but they negated direction and facing. In their saying is contradiction and inconsistency in their concept of Vision, leading to affirming what cannot be seen, and to negating the direction of Absolute Highness established for Allah Almighty.
12 - The Salaf considered what the Maturidiyyah went to regarding the creation of servants' actions as a wrong belief due to containing affirmation of a will for servants independent of Allah Almighty's Will, and that Allah's creation of their actions is only a consequence of their uncreated will. The Salaf believe that to Allah Almighty alone belongs the Will and that servants have a will that does not exit Allah Almighty's Will.
13 - The Maturidiyyah went to say that Faith is Assent by the heart only, and some said: It is Assent by the heart and Confession by the tongue. They forbade its increase and decrease, prohibited Exception in it, and prohibited differentiating between the concept of Faith and Islam.
14 - The Maturidiyyah see that the Fasiq (sinner) is a believer with complete faith.
I ask Allah Almighty to show us the Truth as Truth and grant us following it, and show us Falsehood as Falsehood and grant us avoiding it. And Allah knows best, and may Allah bless and grant peace to our Prophet Muhammad and his family and companions.
